questions.explanation: A double solid yellow line means that it is prohibited for vehicles traveling in either direction to cross the centerline to pass.

questions.question: When approaching a four-way stop, drivers must yield the right-of-way to all motorists who arrived before them.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: At a four-way stop, you must yield the right-of-way to drivers who arrived before you. Wait your turn to enter the intersection.

questions.question: When driving in fog, it is best to drive with:
questions.answerB: Low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: Use low beam headlights when driving in fog, rain, or snow. High beams may reflect off of the weather and make visibility even poorer.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Reserved parking for persons with disabilities.
questions.explanation: This sign is posted on one-way streets and other roadways where a driver is not allowed to enter. A driver may see this sign if attempting to enter an expressway ramp in the wrong direction.

questions.question: Your ability to stop is affected by:
questions.answerB: Other cars on the road.
questions.answerC: The time of day.
questions.explanation: Your ability to stop is greatly affected by the condition of the road. You need to reduce your speed when road conditions are poor in order to maintain control of your vehicle. You will be at risk if you are driving too quickly on roads that are slippery and you need to stop.

questions.question: As you drive, you're required to stop your vehicle:
questions.answerA: At an intersection with a stop sign.
questions.answerB: Where there is a red light.
questions.answerC: When a traffic officer orders you to stop.
questions.explanation: Situations where motorists are required to stop include approaching intersections with stop signs, approaching intersections where a red light is either flashing or illuminated, or any time when a traffic officer orders your vehicle to stop.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane ends, merge left.
questions.answerC: Turn around.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a roundabout is ahead. Enter a roundabout at a low speed and yield to existing traffic.

questions.question: If you are driving and you see animals standing near the roadway:
questions.answerA: Speed up to scare them away.
questions.answerB: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Quickly swerve into the next lane.
questions.explanation: Slow down and proceed with caution if you see animals that are standing near the roadway. They may unexpectedly bolt or change direction at the last moment. Some animals travel in packs, so there may be more animals just out of sight that are also near the road.

questions.question: Which of these is a safe driving technique?
questions.answerA: Using your high beam lights in the fog.
questions.answerB: Staring at the road ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Checking your rearview mirrors frequently.
questions.explanation: To stay aware of hazards, you should scan the road and check your rearview mirrors every two to five seconds. Constantly staring at just the road ahead of you is dangerous. If you must drive in foggy conditions, you should use your low beam headlights, not your high beam headlights.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about blind spots is true?
questions.answerA: Blind spots are eliminated if you have one outside mirror.
questions.answerB: Large trucks have bigger blind spots than most passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Blind spots can be checked by looking in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Even if a vehicle is properly equipped with rearview and outside mirrors, it still has blind spots that cannot be seen in the mirrors. Large trucks have much larger blind spots than most passenger vehicles.

questions.question: A speed limit is:
questions.answerA: The maximum or minimum legal speed you can travel on a road under dangerous conditions.
questions.answerB: The maximum or minimum legal speed you can travel on a road under ideal conditions.
questions.answerC: The suggested speed to travel on a road under ideal conditions.
questions.explanation: A speed limit is the maximum or minimum legal speed you can travel on a road under ideal conditions. You may drive more slowly than the posted speed, but it is illegal to drive any faster. You must drive more slowly where signs or signs indicate a school zone or work zone speed limit. If conditions such as road construction or bad weather make the posted speed unsafe, drive under the speed limit.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Do not enter.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of a winding road ahead.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Watch for traffic merging from the right.
questions.answerB: Merge right.
questions.answerC: Turn left.
questions.explanation: Warning signs alert drivers to upcoming hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about potential traffic merging into their lane from the right.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Right turns are permitted.
questions.answerC: Stop before turning right.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. Right turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: If another car is in danger of hitting you, you should:
questions.answerB: Wave your arms.
questions.answerC: Use your emergency lights.
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used to warn other drivers or pedestrians in situations where they may not see you. For example, if you think another driver is about to hit you, you should sound your horn.

questions.question: When you see other drivers around you acting or reacting in anger:
questions.answerB: Don't react with hand gestures.
questions.answerC: Distance yourself from the situation.
questions.explanation: When other drivers are behaving angrily, you should take action to physically and mentally distance yourself from the situation. Avoid making eye contact with them, or making body movements or gestures that could provoke them. Slow down, move over, or do whatever you safely can to put yourself out of danger.

questions.question: When parallel parking between two cars, you should first:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels to the left.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels to the right.
questions.answerC: Pull up even with the car in front of your desired parking space.
questions.explanation: After finding a parking space, checking traffic, and signaling, you should stop parallel to the vehicle directly ahead of your desired parking space before turning your wheel to park.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Trucks are permitted on an upcoming narrow bridge.
questions.answerB: The bridge ahead is open to one-way traffic only.
questions.answerC: The bridge ahead is wide enough for only one car at a time.
questions.answerD: The bridge ahead may be too narrow to meet or pass a truck.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that an upcoming bridge may be too narrow to meet or pass a truck and that they should be careful.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Low ground railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the overpass ahead has a low clearance. You should not proceed if your vehicle is taller than the height shown on the sign (in this case, 13 feet 6 inches).

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: Reduction in lanes.
questions.explanation: A triangular red and white sign indicates that you must yield the right-of-way.

questions.question: Your blind spot is the area of the road:
questions.answerA: You cannot see without moving your head.
questions.answerB: Directly behind your vehicle.
questions.answerC: You see in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: You see in your side mirror.
questions.explanation: Blind spots are areas that a driver cannot see without moving their head. They can be located to the sides of and behind a vehicle.

questions.question: A good rule to remember for passing is:
questions.answerA: Pass on the right whenever possible.
questions.answerB: Drive with the flow of traffic and pass only as needed.
questions.answerC: Try to get to the front of any slow-moving traffic so that you can see better.
questions.answerD: Always flash your lights and sound your horn to alert other drivers to your intentions.
questions.explanation: Each time you pass another vehicle, there is an increased chance for a collision. If you are moving faster than surrounding traffic, you will have to continue passing others. Drive with the flow of traffic, within the legal speed limit, and pass only as needed.

questions.question: Changing from one lane to another is best done:
questions.answerB: When a car is in your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Gradually and carefully.
questions.explanation: You should always change lanes gradually and carefully. Only change lanes when necessary. Every lane change increases the possibility of a traffic accident.

questions.question: If you see orange construction signs and cones on a freeway, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down because the lane ends ahead.
questions.answerB: Be prepared for workers and equipment ahead.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and maintain your current speed.
questions.explanation: As you enter a work zone, signs and message boards will warn you of workers, slow-moving equipment, and/or closed lanes ahead. You should reduce your speed and be prepared to slow down or stop.

questions.question: Which of the following are factors commonly contributing to traffic crashes?
questions.answerA: Exceeding the posted speed limit and driving too fast for conditions or circumstances.
questions.answerB: Getting adequate rest and staying alert.
questions.answerC: Scanning the environment and staying focused on the driving task.
questions.explanation: Driving above the speed limit, driving too far below the speed limit, and driving too fast for conditions are all actions that commonly contribute to traffic accidents. Always drive with the general flow of traffic, within legal speed limits.

questions.question: When approaching a disabled pedestrian using a guide dog, white cane, or other assistive device, a driver should yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: A pedestrian with a disability who is utilizing a guide dog, a white cane, a wheelchair, or another assistive device, whether on a sidewalk or roadway, has the right-of-way and is granted the same rights as any other pedestrian.

questions.question: Drivers are required to obey instructions from:
questions.answerB: Other drivers whose vehicles are broken down on the roadway.
questions.answerC: Flaggers (signal persons) at construction sites.
questions.explanation: Drivers must obey special signs or instructions given by flaggers. They are in place to keep drivers and workers safe.

questions.question: Drowsy drivers:
questions.answerA: Should drink strong black coffee to stay awake.
questions.answerB: Can drive so poorly that they may appear to be drunk.
questions.answerC: Can stay alert by opening a window and turning up the radio.
questions.explanation: Drowsiness can make people drive so poorly that they appear to be drunk. Opening a window, turning on the radio, or drinking coffee is not enough to make a drowsy driver alert to roadway hazards.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Curve.
questions.answerC: Turn right or left.
questions.answerD: Traffic flows only in the direction of the arrow.
questions.explanation: This one-way sign indicates that traffic flows only in the direction of the arrow.

questions.question: You must stop at a railroad crossing when:
questions.answerA: Directed to do so by a flagger.
questions.answerB: It is controlled by a stop sign.
questions.answerC: Flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign. Stop when flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.

questions.question: Which lane must you be in before making a left turn from a one-way street?
questions.answerA: The lane nearest the left curb.
questions.answerB: The lane nearest the center of the street.
questions.answerC: The lane nearest the right curb.
questions.explanation: When making any turn, turn from the lane closest to the direction you wish to travel into the first available legal lane. If you are making a left turn from a one-way street, this means that you would make the turn from the lane nearest to the left curb.

questions.question: The best way to avoid loss of control under wet conditions is to increase your vehicle's speed.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: As you drive on a wet road, your tires may start to ride up on the surface of water, causing you to lose control of your vehicle. This is called hydroplaning. The best way to avoid hydroplaning is to lower your speed when driving under wet conditions.

questions.question: Drivers must yield to a pedestrian:
questions.answerA: Even if the pedestrian crosses the street carelessly.
questions.answerB: Only when the pedestrian is in a crosswalk.
questions.answerC: Only if the pedestrian is on the same side of the road as the driver.
questions.answerD: If the pedestrian uses a hand signal to ask oncoming drivers to stop.
questions.explanation: Drivers must always yield to pedestrians in the street, even if they are crossing against a red light or are otherwise being careless.

questions.question: A railroad crossbuck sign should be treated the same as a yield sign.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: A railroad crossing crossbuck sign is considered a yield sign and a driver must yield the right-of-way to any oncoming trains and railroad equipment.

questions.question: You do not have to stop for a school bus that is stopped with its red lights flashing if it is on a private road.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When a school bus is stopped with its red lights flashing and stop arm out, other drivers are required to stop. This law applies to drivers traveling on both public and private roads.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Merge.
questions.answerC: Upcoming change in direction.
questions.explanation: An eight-sided red sign means "stop."

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Watch for drunk drivers.
questions.answerC: Dangerous curve ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign warns drivers to be extra careful when the pavement is wet because the road may become slippery, making vehicles more difficult to control.

questions.question: Car drivers should know that large trucks:
questions.answerB: Can stop more quickly than passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Do not need more room to maneuver than passenger vehicles.
questions.explanation: A large truck has large blind spots to the front, sides, and rear of the vehicle. Avoid lingering in these areas. Because of their larger size and weight, trucks require more room to maneuver and stop than passenger vehicles.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: Guide signs are ____ signs that provide directional and mileage information to drivers.
questions.answerB: Red
questions.answerC: Green
questions.explanation: Guide signs, sometimes known as destination signs, have a green background and provide directional and mileage information to specific destinations. They can be a helpful resource when driving in unfamiliar locations.

questions.question: Larger vehicles have:
questions.answerB: Smaller blind spots.
questions.answerC: No blind spots.
questions.answerD: The same blind spots as smaller vehicles.
questions.explanation: The larger the vehicle, the larger the blind spots. Large trucks and SUVs have spots close to their rears that cannot be seen in their side or rearview mirrors.

questions.question: When the driver behind you wants to pass, you should:
questions.answerB: Go the same speed.
questions.answerC: Slow down to allow room in front of your vehicle for the other driver to complete the pass easily.
questions.explanation: When the driver behind you wants to pass, you should slow down so that there is enough room in front of your vehicle for the other driver to complete their pass. This will allow them to complete the passing maneuver in less time and more easily.

questions.question: On an undivided highway, if an emergency vehicle approaches while using its siren and flashing lights, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive slowly until it has passed.
questions.answerB: Speed up to clear traffic.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right and stop.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to a police vehicle, fire engine, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle using a siren or air horn and red or blue flashing lights. Pull over to the right edge of the road, or as near to the right side as possible, when you see or hear an emergency vehicle approaching from any direction on an undivided highway.

questions.question: You should increase the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead when you:
questions.answerA: Are following a small passenger vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are being tailgated by another driver.
questions.answerC: Are driving more slowly than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: When being tailgated, create extra space in front of your vehicle and do not brake suddenly. Slow down gradually or merge into another lane to prevent a collision with the tailgater.

questions.question: Orange is the color of signs used to communicate with drivers in construction work zones.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Most signs in work areas are orange and diamond-shaped, although some signs are rectangular. These signs and traffic control devices are commonly reflective to better attract your attention at night.

questions.question: If you are involved in a serious motor vehicle crash:
questions.answerB: Call the police.
questions.answerC: Determine if anyone is injured.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, move your vehicle off of the road and stop, if possible. If anyone is injured, call 911 and provide appropriate help. You must report the crash to law enforcement if there is an injury, a death, and/or more than $1,000 in property damage (or more than $200 worth of damage made to non-vehicle government property, such as signs or guardrails).

questions.question: It is unlawful in Iowa for any driver to read, write, or send a text message while driving.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: It is unlawful for any driver in Iowa to read, write, or send a text message while driving. Before using an electronic communication device to write, send, or read a text message, a driver must safely bring their vehicle to a complete stop off the traveled portion of the roadway.

questions.question: If your vehicle has a two-part safety belt system, you should:
questions.answerB: Use both the lap and shoulder belts.
questions.answerC: Use only the shoulder belt.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has a two-part seat belt system, be sure to wear both the lap belt and the shoulder belt. Wearing either part alone greatly reduces your protection. If you have an automatic shoulder belt, be sure to buckle your lap belt as well.

questions.question: If worried, nervous, angry, or crying, a driver:
questions.answerA: Will drive no differently than they would if they were thinking more clearly.
questions.answerB: Can drive faster because they are more in touch with their senses.
questions.answerC: Should take the time to focus on driving before starting the engine.
questions.answerD: Should call a friend to vent while driving.
questions.explanation: You may not be able to drive well if you are worried, excited, crying, angry, or depressed. Emotions can distract you from your driving because your mind is focused on something else. Take time to calm down and get focused before driving.

questions.question: You must obey instructions from school crossing guards:
questions.answerB: Only during school hours.
questions.answerC: Unless you do not see any children present.
questions.explanation: Drivers should be alert to the presence of crossing guards when near a school and must always obey their instructions.

questions.question: When driving in rain, you must:
questions.answerB: Use high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Use parking lights.
questions.explanation: In rainy conditions, you should use your low beam headlights.

questions.question: You are involved in a minor collision at an intersection. There are no injuries and there is very little vehicle damage. You should:
questions.answerA: Leave your vehicle in the traffic lane until law enforcement arrives.
questions.answerB: Move your vehicle out of the traffic lane, if possible.
questions.answerC: Not move your vehicle for any reason.
questions.explanation: After a collision, if no one has been injured or killed and you can safely do so, you should move your vehicle out of the traffic lane.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The left lane is reserved for vehicles with a specific number of occupants.
questions.answerB: Specific turning movements are allowed from specific lanes.
questions.answerC: Do not enter.
questions.answerD: Drivers in both lanes are responsible for merging smoothly.
questions.explanation: This sign marks a high occupancy vehicle (HOV) lane. HOV lanes are reserved for use by buses and vehicles with a driver and one or more passengers, as indicated on the sign.

questions.question: Highway markings:
questions.answerB: Are only found in construction zones.
questions.answerC: Provide information for drivers.
questions.answerD: Are usually red and blue in color.
questions.explanation: Highway markings provide information for drivers. Markings help drivers correctly position their vehicles on roadways, inform drivers of safe passing zones, and warn drivers about upcoming conditions.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: A road joins from the right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead turns sharply right then sharply left.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that the road ahead will turn sharply to the right and then sharply to the left.

questions.question: You can drive off the road to pass another vehicle:
questions.answerA: If the vehicle ahead is turning left.
questions.answerB: If there are two or more lanes traveling in your direction.
questions.answerC: Under no circumstances.
questions.explanation: You may never drive off the paved or main-traveled portion of the road and onto the shoulder to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: Check your rearview mirrors:
questions.answerA: Often to see how traffic is moving behind you.
questions.answerB: To see if a vehicle is in your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Only when you are slowing down.
questions.explanation: When driving, do not develop a fixed stare. Frequently check your rearview mirrors so you know the positions of vehicles near you.

questions.question: Drivers must be careful when passing large vehicles and should avoid driving beside large vehicles for long periods of time.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Because large vehicles have large blind spots on both sides, you should avoid driving beside a large vehicle for a long period of time. It is safest for you to either drop back or move forward when you find yourself directly next to a large vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following does not happen after drinking?
questions.answerA: Your reflexes and reaction time slow down.
questions.answerB: Your judgement of speed and distance is distorted.
questions.answerC: You are less alert.
questions.answerD: You calm down and can concentrate better.
questions.explanation: Alcohol reduces your reaction time, reduces your ability to see clearly, changes your judgment of speed and distances, reduces your ability to recover from the glare of headlights, and often reduces your inhibitions and makes you more likely to take risks.

questions.question: The driver ahead of you stops at a crosswalk. What should you do?
questions.answerA: Cautiously pass the vehicle at 10 mph or slower.
questions.answerB: Stop, proceeding only when all the pedestrians have crossed.
questions.answerC: Change lanes, look carefully, and pass the stopped vehicle.
questions.explanation: You must not pass a vehicle that is stopped at a crosswalk. There may be pedestrians crossing the street that you cannot see. Instead, stop, proceeding only after all pedestrians have crossed.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You must turn left or right.
questions.answerB: You are approaching a T intersection.
questions.answerC: The road that you are on intersects with a divided highway.
questions.answerD: You are on an overpass above a divided highway.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road that you are on intersects with a divided highway. A divided highway is two one-way roadways separated by a median or guide rail.

questions.question: When turning left at an intersection:
questions.answerA: You should always yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic and pedestrians should yield to you.
questions.answerC: You should never yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.explanation: When turning left at an intersection, yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic and pedestrians. Once the intersection is clear and applicable signals allow, you may complete the turn.

questions.question: A driver approaching a flashing red traffic signal must:
questions.answerB: Drive carefully without stopping.
questions.answerC: Merge to the right.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means that you must stop, yield to traffic and pedestrians, and go only when it is safe. At a railroad crossing, a flashing red light indicates that a train is approaching. Yield to the train, and go only when the lights have stopped flashing and all other active warning devices deactivate.

questions.question: Allow extra space in front of your vehicle when following a:
questions.answerB: Passenger vehicle.
questions.answerC: Motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Allow for extra space when driving behind a motorcycle. Motorcycles can stop more quickly than other vehicles can and you must have adequate room to stop if the motorcyclist brakes or falls off. Also, remember that motorcycles are difficult to see at night because they only have one tail light.

questions.question: If you are stopped by a police officer, you should:
questions.answerA: Unbuckle your seat belt and lower your window.
questions.answerB: Get your paperwork ready before the officer reaches your car.
questions.answerC: Stay in your vehicle with your hands on the steering wheel and wait for the officer to approach you.
questions.answerD: Get out of your car and walk toward the patrol car.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped by the police, keep your hands on the wheel and ask any passengers to keep their hands in view as well. You should remain in the vehicle unless the police officer asks you to get out. Wait until the officer asks you to retrieve your driver license, registration, and insurance cards.

questions.question: What is a "No zone?"
questions.answerB: A one-way traffic area
questions.answerC: The blind spot of a large vehicle
questions.answerD: An area designated for motor vehicles
questions.explanation: "No zones" are the large blind spots around trucks and other large vehicles. Drivers of smaller vehicles should avoid lingering in "No zones."

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: One-way traffic ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you must keep to the right of the upcoming divider.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Turn right after making a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Right turns are not permitted.
questions.answerC: Left turns are permitted.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs display laws that drivers must always obey. Right turns are not permitted where this sign is present.

questions.question: Slowing down just to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary:
questions.answerB: Prevents rear-end collisions.
questions.answerC: Improves traffic flow by preventing collisions.
questions.explanation: Avoid "rubbernecking," or slowing down to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary. This helps to relieve traffic congestion.

questions.question: A red flashing traffic light has the same meaning as a:
questions.answerB: Stop sign.
questions.answerC: Yield sign.
questions.explanation: A red flashing traffic signal has the same meaning as a stop sign. When approaching a red flashing signal, come to a complete stop and proceed when it is safe to do so. A stop sign may sometimes also be posted where this signal is located.

questions.question: If another driver cuts you off in traffic, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull next to the driver and yell at them.
questions.answerB: Let it go.
questions.answerC: Flash your high beams at the driver.
questions.answerD: Get back at the other driver by cutting them off.
questions.explanation: To avoid the dangers of road rage, you should never take it personally if another driver cuts you off in traffic. Just let it go and continue driving safely.

questions.question: A motorist making a left turn at an intersection must yield the right-of-way to a bicyclist entering the intersection from the opposite direction.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When turning left at an intersection, you must yield to oncoming bicycles in the same manner that you would yield to oncoming motor vehicles. Keep your wheels straight while waiting to turn and proceed when the way is clear of traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: The posted maximum speed limit is the fastest you can drive in an area.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: The posted maximum speed limit is the fastest legal driving speed in an area, under ideal conditions. You must reduce your speed when conditions require it, such as when the roadway is slippery or when it is difficult to see clearly down the road.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you can check your blind spot by:
questions.answerB: Turning your head and looking over your shoulder.
questions.answerC: Using your side mirror.
questions.explanation: Even if your vehicle is properly equipped with mirrors, there are blind spots that cannot be seen by using the mirrors. Before changing lanes, look over your shoulder to check these areas.

questions.question: Alcohol is the single greatest common factor in fatal motor vehicle crashes.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Alcohol is the number one killer on American roadways. Alcohol affects a person’s vision and slows their reaction time, so it takes longer to act in an emergency. Alcohol affects a person’s driving even if they are below the level of illegal intoxication.

questions.question: There are oncoming vehicles to your left and a row of parked vehicles to your right. You should steer:
questions.answerA: Closer to the oncoming vehicles than the parked vehicles.
questions.answerB: Closer to the parked vehicles than the oncoming vehicles.
questions.answerC: A middle course between the oncoming and parked vehicles.
questions.explanation: If there are oncoming vehicles to your left and a row of parked vehicles to your right, the best thing to do is to split the difference. Steer a middle course between the oncoming cars and the parked cars.

questions.question: When turning left, drivers must yield the right-of-way to:
questions.answerA: Other drivers who are already in the intersection.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians who are already in the intersection.
questions.explanation: When turning left, drivers must yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic. Drivers must also always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians, bicyclists, and other drivers who are already in the intersection.

questions.question: In rainy weather, you should be most careful when turning or stopping:
questions.answerA: After it has been raining all day.
questions.answerB: One half hour after it stops raining.
questions.answerC: During the first half hour of rain.
questions.explanation: You should be extra careful when turning and stopping during the first half hour of rain. At this point, the oil from cars has not yet washed off the pavement and could be forming a slippery mixture with the rain.

questions.question: A flashing red light on a traffic signal means:
questions.answerA: The same thing as a stop sign.
questions.answerB: The traffic signal is broken.
questions.answerC: You do not have to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means the same thing as a stop sign. If you encounter a flashing red light, you should come to a complete stop, yield to appropriate traffic and pedestrians, and only proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: You are waiting to turn left at a multilane intersection and opposing traffic is blocking your view. You should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate rapidly when the first lane you need to cross is clear.
questions.answerB: Wait until you can see all the lanes you need to cross before going ahead with your turn.
questions.answerC: Wait for an oncoming driver to wave you across the intersection.
questions.answerD: Edge your car into each lane of opposing traffic as soon as it clears.
questions.explanation: You should never start a left turn until you can see that all the lanes you need to cross are clear and that you can safely make the turn.

questions.question: Pentagonal signs indicate:
questions.answerB: School zones.
questions.answerC: Speed limits.
questions.explanation: Pentagonal signs indicate that you are in a school zone. Be extra alert to children and pedestrians when driving near a school.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Low clearance.
questions.answerC: Merging traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers to be aware of potential traffic entering from an upcoming side road.

questions.question: You are driving on a divided multilane highway and see or hear the signal of an approaching emergency vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Disregard the signal if there are other lanes available for the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop as quickly as you can.
questions.answerC: Slow down, move your vehicle to provide a clear path for the emergency vehicle, and stop.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to get out of the way of the emergency vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you hear the siren or see the flashing lights of an emergency vehicle, you must slow down, provide a clear path for the vehicle, and stop. Don't try to outdrive the emergency vehicle.

questions.question: If you want to get off the freeway but you have missed your exit, you should:
questions.answerB: Make a U-turn through the median.
questions.answerC: Pull onto the shoulder and back your car to the exit.
questions.answerD: Flag down a police officer for an escort back to your exit.
questions.explanation: If you miss your exit, you should take the next exit. Do not stop or back up on the highway, swerve across multiple lanes to try to make the exit at the last second, or cross over the median to turn around. All of these maneuvers are illegal and extremely dangerous.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: When pavement is wet, reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: The road ahead winds in a series of turns or curves.
questions.answerC: Traffic increases ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that the roadway will be slippery when wet and they should reduce their speed accordingly.

questions.question: You may pass another vehicle:
questions.answerA: In a curve or on a hill because the chance is small that another vehicle is coming.
questions.answerB: By using the shoulder of the highway.
questions.answerC: If your lane is next to a solid yellow line and the passing lane is clear ahead.
questions.explanation: You may not pass another vehicle on a hill or in a curve because you cannot see oncoming traffic and may cause a collision. Never pass another vehicle by driving onto the shoulder of a highway. Passing another vehicle by driving over a solid yellow line is prohibited.

questions.question: Railroad crossings should always be considered:
questions.answerA: Safe to cross, as it is unlikely that a train will be coming.
questions.answerB: Dangerous.
questions.answerC: Safe locations to park a car.
questions.answerD: A place where it is required to stop
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings are always dangerous. Drivers should always look and listen for trains approaching from either direction on all railroad tracks. Always follow the directions indicated by signs, signals, and flaggers. Never proceed past a railroad crossing until you are certain it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Consuming which of the following substances may impair your ability to drive safely and may result in an arrest for driving under the influence of intoxicants (DUII)?
questions.answerB: Controlled substances, such as illegal drugs or prescription medicines
questions.answerC: Inhalants, such as glue or paint
questions.explanation: A wide variety of intoxicants can impair your ability to drive. These include all types of alcoholic beverages, illegal drugs, inhalants, and many legal medications (both prescription and over-the-counter).

questions.question: This sign is a:
questions.answerB: School crossing sign.
questions.answerC: Stop sign.
questions.explanation: A downward-facing triangular sign is always a yield sign. Drivers must be prepared to slow down or stop when approaching a yield sign.

questions.question: Which of the following is a dangerous habit when driving in work zones?
questions.answerB: Failing to carefully watch for workers and moving equipment
questions.answerC: Both of the above
questions.explanation: When driving in a work zone, adjust your speed for the traffic conditions and don't follow other vehicles too closely. Be attentive to workers and machines in the work zone.

questions.question: A person who drives much slower than the speed limit:
questions.answerB: Always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Should not let following cars pass.
questions.answerD: May create a dangerous driving environment.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than the flow of traffic can be hazardous. If you are on a two-lane, two-way road and driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you are required to pull off the road and let the other vehicles pass. Only drive significantly under the speed limit when conditions require it.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You must travel at the speed indicated.
questions.answerB: The maximum legal speed on the roadway is 55 mph.
questions.answerC: You must travel through the intersection at the posted speed.
questions.explanation: This is a speed limit sign. It indicates the maximum legal speed that you may drive on the road where it is posted. At times of rain, snow, ice, or other less-than-ideal conditions, you may have to drive more slowly than the posted limit.

questions.question: Large vehicles have blind spots that can extend up to 200 feet directly behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Large vehicles have blind spots that can extend up to 200 feet directly behind the vehicle. Do not tailgate a large vehicle as they will have no way of knowing that you are there.

questions.question: Because driving involves some risk, it is wise to continually improve your driving and observation skills.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Driving can become unsafe if drivers believe they have nothing to improve. For your safety and the safety of others, always strive to improve your driving and observation skills.

questions.question: Two solid white lines painted across a traffic lane show the boundaries of a crosswalk. As a driver, you should know that:
questions.answerA: Motor vehicles have the right-of-way over pedestrians in crosswalks.
questions.answerB: When pedestrians are in crosswalks, they should be given the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: No one has the right-of-way in a crosswalk.
questions.answerD: Pedestrians are responsible to stay out of the way of all traffic.
questions.explanation: Crosswalk lines show pedestrians where to safely cross a road or street. Crosswalks may be marked by horizontal lines, vertical lines, or a combination of the two. You must always stop for pedestrians who are in a crosswalk.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Cars on the right move first.
questions.answerB: You have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Let cross traffic pass before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When approaching this sign, you must yield the right-of-way. Slow down and let vehicles and pedestrians crossing your path pass before you proceed. If necessary, stop before going ahead.

questions.question: Give the right-of-way to any pedestrian who is:
questions.answerB: In any crosswalk or intersection.
questions.answerC: Crossing any street.
questions.explanation: Drivers must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians who are crossing the street in any marked or unmarked crosswalk. In the interest of safety, drivers should yield the right-of-way to people crossing any street.

questions.question: How fast you drive does not affect the distance your vehicle travels after you brake to come to a stop.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: When driving in high-speed traffic, it is extremely important to stay well behind the vehicle in front of you. As your speed increases, the distance it will take for your vehicle to stop also increases.

questions.question: When you drive through an area where children are playing, you should expect them:
questions.answerA: To know when it is safe to cross the street.
questions.answerB: To stop at the curb before crossing the street.
questions.answerC: To run out in front of you without looking.
questions.answerD: Not to cross the street unless they are with an adult.
questions.explanation: You should always reduce your speed and use extra caution when children are in the vicinity. They may fail to understand the danger and may run out in front of you without looking.

questions.question: The most effective thing you can do to reduce your risk of being injured or killed in a traffic crash is to:
questions.answerB: Limit your driving to weekdays.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane on multilane highways.
questions.answerD: Limit your driving to hours between 3:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m.
questions.explanation: Wearing your seat belt is the single most effective thing you can do to reduce your risk of death or injury while driving.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: Slow down and prepare to stop if cars are approaching you.
questions.answerB: Come to a full stop and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Proceed carefully through the intersection, not always stopping.
questions.answerD: Stop only for traffic on an intersecting road.
questions.explanation: A stop sign means that you must come to a full stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in or heading toward the intersection. Go again when it is safe.

questions.question: Stopping distances and severity of crashes:
questions.answerB: Are not affected by vehicle speed.
questions.answerC: Increase as vehicle speed increases.
questions.explanation: Stopping distances are longer and crashes are more severe when traffic travels at higher speeds.

questions.question: You should honk your horn when you:
questions.answerB: Are passing a bicyclist.
questions.answerC: See a child who is about to run into the street.
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used as a warning in situations where you think another driver or a pedestrian does not see you. For example, if a child begins to run into the street in front of your vehicle, you should sound your horn.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Merging traffic from the right.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign tells drivers to prepare to allow traffic to safely merge from the right.

questions.question: When you hear the siren or see the flashing lights of an approaching emergency vehicle, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down until it passes you.
questions.answerB: Drive to the right side of the road and stop.
questions.answerC: Motion for the emergency vehicle to pass you.
questions.answerD: Merge into the right lane and continue driving.
questions.explanation: Yield the right-of-way to any approaching emergency vehicle that is using its flashing lights or siren, regardless of its direction of travel. You must immediately drive to the right side of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle has passed. If you are within an intersection, pass through the intersection before coming to a stop on the right side of the road.

questions.question: Passing is prohibited:
questions.answerA: Within 100 feet of an intersection or railroad crossing.
questions.answerB: If the vehicle you are following has a slow-moving vehicle symbol.
questions.answerC: When using the right lane to pass a left-turning vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is against the law to pass any vehicle within 100 feet of a railroad crossing or intersection. Only pass where it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: To know where traffic is behind you:
questions.answerB: Turn and look out your back window.
questions.answerC: Keep other vehicles out of your blind spots.
questions.explanation: Drivers should check their rearview mirrors often to stay aware of the position of traffic behind them.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The road ahead turns sharply right, then left.
questions.answerB: The road ahead turns sharply left, then right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead curves to the left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead will turn sharply to the right and then to the left.

questions.question: This sign indicates that:
questions.answerA: There is a steep hill ahead.
questions.answerB: No trucks are allowed on an upcoming hill.
questions.answerC: A logging road is ahead.
questions.answerD: There are trucks on an upcoming hill.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that there is a steep hill or downgrade ahead.

questions.question: If you are feeling fatigued while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to reach your destination more quickly.
questions.answerB: Increase the volume of your radio.
questions.answerC: Find a safe parking area to take a short nap.
questions.explanation: When driving, watch for warning signs of fatigue. You are too tired to drive safely if you are struggling to keep your eyes open, drifting from your lane, or turning up the radio and rolling down your windows to keep yourself awake. If you notice these signs, it is a good idea to find a safe place to park so you can refresh yourself with a short nap.

questions.question: When passing on a multilane highway:
questions.answerA: Be sure the passing lane is clear.
questions.answerB: Pass only on the right.
questions.answerC: Watch for oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: There is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: Before passing, you must make sure the passing lane is clear and give the proper turn signal to show you are going to change lanes.

questions.question: If you come to an intersection and your view to the side is blocked, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and look both ways.
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed and look both ways.
questions.answerC: Stop, then inch forward until you can see clearly in both directions.
questions.explanation: Drivers must slow down when approaching an intersection. If a clear view of cross traffic is obscured, a driver should come to a stop and inch forward until they can see clearly in both directions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that left turns are prohibited.

questions.question: To pass a slower-moving vehicle on a two-lane, two-way road, you must:
questions.answerB: Flash your lights at oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Use the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Use the lane that belongs to oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: Passing on a two-lane, two-way road requires good judgment because you must use the lane belonging to oncoming traffic to complete your pass. Only pass if you may safely and legally do so.

questions.question: A leaking exhaust system can:
questions.answerB: Require your vehicle to have a tune-up sooner than normal.
questions.answerC: Make you drowsy while driving.
questions.answerD: Set grass fires on country roads.
questions.explanation: The exhaust system helps remove toxic gases, reduce the noise, and cool the hot gases coming from a running engine. Fumes from a leaky exhaust system can cause death in a very short time. They can also make you drowsy while driving.

questions.question: Which of the following are used on some highways to direct drivers into the proper lanes for turning?
questions.answerB: Flashing yellow lights
questions.answerC: White lines on the side of the road
questions.answerD: White arrows in the middle of the lanes
questions.explanation: Arrows may be used to indicate which lanes should be used for specific purposes, such as driving straight or making a turn.

questions.question: You are coming to a railroad crossing where the crossing signals are flashing. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop and look for a train.
questions.answerB: Slow down and look for a train.
questions.answerC: Look for a train, then speed up.
questions.answerD: Do what the vehicle ahead of you does.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing, you must stop your vehicle no closer than 15 feet from the nearest rail if an installed electric or mechanical signal is giving warning of an approaching train. Be aware of other warning signs that may indicate an oncoming train, including seeing a lowered crossing gate or hearing an oncoming train.

questions.question: Stop lines are solid white lines painted across traffic lanes:
questions.answerB: Next to churches and schools.
questions.answerC: At intersections and pedestrian crosswalks.
questions.explanation: Stop lines are solid white lines painted across traffic lanes at intersections and pedestrian crosswalks. They indicate the exact location at which approaching drivers must stop.

questions.question: Remove all snow, frost, and ice from:
questions.answerB: All windows.
questions.answerC: Just the windshield and passenger window.
questions.explanation: It is important that you are able to see clearly through all of your vehicle's windows, including the windshield. Remove all snow, ice, and frost from your vehicle's windows and mirrors before you start to drive.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop ahead.
questions.answerC: Roadwork or maintenance is present.
questions.explanation: Orange, diamond-shaped signs are used to mark construction, maintenance, survey, and utility work areas. These signs help direct drivers and pedestrians safely through dangerous zones. Fines for traffic convictions may double in areas marked by these signs.

questions.question: Prior to entering a curve:
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerC: Brake hard.
questions.explanation: You may drive more slowly than the posted speed limit, based on road conditions, but it is illegal to drive any faster than the posted speed limit. Some conditions which require reduced speed for safety include approaching curves or hills where visibility is limited, driving on slippery roads, and driving on roads where animals and pedestrians are present.

questions.question: Tailgating other drivers (driving too closely to their rear bumper):
questions.answerA: Can frustrate other drivers and make them angry.
questions.answerB: Cannot result in a traffic citation.
questions.answerC: Reduces collisions by preventing being "cut off."
questions.explanation: Tailgating is a common behavior that can lead to aggressive driving, and so it should be avoided. Drivers may face legal consequences for driving unsafely.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You are about to enter a one-way street from the wrong direction.
questions.answerB: U-turns are prohibited.
questions.answerC: You may proceed if the way is clear.
questions.explanation: This sign marks a one-way road, entrance, or exit. If you are facing this sign, traffic is coming toward you. Turn around if you are driving toward this sign.

questions.question: What does a single dashed white line separating traffic mean?
questions.answerA: Drivers may pass, even if it could be dangerous.
questions.answerB: Lanes move in opposite directions.
questions.answerC: Drivers may not pass.
questions.answerD: Drivers may pass if it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: White lines separate lanes of traffic that are moving in the same direction. Dashed white lines may be crossed to pass or change lanes, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: While driving, you come upon a sign displaying the words “Reduced speed, 35 mph." This means:
questions.answerA: That the new 35 mph speed limit begins at this sign.
questions.answerB: That the new 35 mph speed limit begins at the next speed limit sign.
questions.answerC: That you have plenty of time to slow down before the reduced speed zone.
questions.answerD: That you should reduce your speed to 35 mph, but only under poor weather conditions.
questions.explanation: "Reduced speed" signs inform drivers that they must reduce their speeds. If a new speed limit is posted on one of these signs, the new speed limit begins at the sign.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Side Road.
questions.answerC: Railroad Warning.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a stop sign is ahead.

questions.question: If there is no crosswalk and you see a pedestrian crossing your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the pedestrian can see you before proceeding.
questions.answerB: Cautiously drive around the pedestrian.
questions.answerC: Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing.
questions.explanation: Drivers must always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians in the roadway, even if there is not a marked crosswalk.

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.answerA: You should put on your cruise control near a railroad crossing to maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerB: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign.
questions.answerC: You have the right-of-way at a railroad crossing and do not need to stop.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger, stop sign, or warning signal. Use caution when driving near railroad tracks.

questions.question: When you approach a railroad crossing without flashing warning signals or crossing gates, you should:
questions.answerA: Cross the tracks immediately and as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Always stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: Prepare to yield to any train at the crossing.
questions.answerD: Speed up to beat any oncoming train.
questions.explanation: Always be prepared to yield to any oncoming trains before crossing railroad tracks, particularly if there are no lights or gates controlling the crossing. Never start to cross the tracks until there is room for your entire vehicle on the other side of the tracks. Due to the risk of a vehicle stalling, it is not wise to shift gears when crossing railroad tracks.

questions.question: This road sign indicates:
questions.answerA: The maximum safe speed for a residential area.
questions.answerB: The maximum safe speed for an expressway exit.
questions.answerC: The maximum safe speed for an expressway entrance.
questions.answerD: The maximum safe speed for a work zone.
questions.explanation: This advisory speed sign indicates the maximum safe speed for a highway exit (in this example, 30 mph).

questions.question: When changing lanes you should not:
questions.answerA: Check your side and rearview mirrors.
questions.answerB: Give a turn signal to signal your intentions.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers who may be moving into the same lane as you.
questions.answerD: Use your cell phone to contact the police to determine if the road ahead is clear.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check your side and rearview mirrors for traffic approaching you from behind. Use your turn signal to let other drivers know you plan to change lanes. Check for other drivers who also may be moving into the same lane.

questions.question: To prepare for anything coming up on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerA: Continually scan the entire road and all roadsides.
questions.answerB: Stare straight ahead at all times.
questions.answerC: Drive with your left foot resting lightly on the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Maintain focus toward the middle of the road.
questions.explanation: Your ability to handle dangerous traffic situations depends largely on searching for and identifying problems before meeting them. Looking far ahead of your vehicle does not mean you should simply stare at the center of the road. You need to continually scan the entire road, including the sides of the road.

questions.question: If a flagger is directing traffic in a construction zone, you must:
questions.answerA: Follow the directions given by the flagger.
questions.answerB: Copy what surrounding traffic is doing, despite the flagger's instructions.
questions.answerC: Assume the flagger is not supposed to be directing traffic.
questions.answerD: Follow the laws that would be in place if the area was not under construction.
questions.explanation: Be prepared to reduce your speed and use caution when directed to do so by a sign, flagger, or law enforcement officer. Failure to do so is illegal and is dangerous to those working in construction zones.

questions.question: Blue traffic signs offer information on:
questions.answerB: Construction and maintenance.
questions.answerC: Mileage information, such as distances to specific locations.
questions.explanation: Blue signs on the roadway are service signs. They are used to provide information about motorist services, such as upcoming rest areas, food options, or nearby hospitals.

questions.question: You see a school bus using flashing amber lights. What is the bus driver doing?
questions.answerB: Signaling to other motorists that the bus will soon be stopping to load or unload school children.
questions.answerC: Preparing to make a turn.
questions.explanation: When you meet a school bus that is displaying flashing amber lights, you must drive no faster than 20 mph and be prepared to stop. You may not pass a school bus when its amber lights are flashing.

questions.question: It is important to slow down:
questions.answerB: At intersections or railroad crossings.
questions.answerC: When the road is wet or slippery.
questions.explanation: You should always slow down when driving on narrow or winding roads, near intersections, near railroad crossings, on hills, in sharp or blind curves, where there are pedestrians or driving hazards, and when the roads are wet or slippery.

questions.question: When stopped at a red traffic light with a green arrow, you may proceed in the direction of the arrow if you:
questions.answerA: First come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Wait until the light changes.
questions.answerC: Are in the proper lane and the intersection is clear.
questions.explanation: You may proceed in the direction that a green arrow signal is pointing if you are in the proper lane, regardless of any other signals that are displayed. Before turning, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and vehicles already within the intersection.

questions.question: Only vehicles displaying special plates or parking placards for persons with disabilities may park in spaces reserved for them by an official sign.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: A parking space marked by a "Reserved Parking for Persons with Disabilities" sign may only be used by vehicles that display Persons with Disabilities license plates, Disabled Veteran license plates, and/or disabled parking placards.

questions.question: When preparing to make a left turn from a two-way street, you should drive:
questions.answerA: Near the right-hand side of the road.
questions.answerB: Near the centerline.
questions.answerC: On the left of the centerline.
questions.explanation: When you are turning left from a two-way street, begin in the lane closest to the centerline and start your turn just before the front of your car reaches the center of the intersection. Do not cut the corner. Steering hand-over-hand, turn into the first available legal lane.

questions.question: Taking drugs along with alcohol:
questions.answerA: Increases the risk of causing a crash.
questions.answerB: Is no more dangerous than consuming alcohol by itself.
questions.answerC: Lessens the effect of alcohol on your ability to drive.
questions.answerD: Has no effect on your general driving ability.
questions.explanation: Drugs (including illegal, prescription, and over-the-counter medications) can affect your brain function and impair your ability to drive safely. Combining alcohol with other drugs will increase the risk of a crash.

questions.question: A steady green light at an intersection means that you:
questions.answerA: Must slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.answerB: Must stop and check for oncoming traffic before proceeding.
questions.answerC: May drive through the intersection if the road is clear.
questions.explanation: A steady green light means you may drive through the intersection if the road is clear. You may also turn right or left on a steady green light unless a sign prohibits the turn. When turning, you must yield to other vehicles and pedestrians within the intersection.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for people crossing your path.
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: Work zone ahead.
questions.explanation: This orange warning sign tells drivers that an area of roadwork is upcoming. When traveling through a work zone, stay alert for temporary traffic control devices.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You are about to enter a one-way street the wrong way.
questions.answerB: School crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Do not drive in this lane.
questions.answerD: Traffic turning left on the green light must yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: This sign is used with a traffic signal to tell drivers that left-turning traffic does not have the right-of-way and must instead wait for oncoming traffic to clear.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Low shoulder.
questions.answerC: No parking at any time.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers should keep right to avoid an upcoming potential driving hazard.

questions.question: If the driver of an oncoming vehicle fails to dim their headlights:
questions.answerA: Look toward the center of the roadway.
questions.answerB: Look toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerC: Look straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If an oncoming driver fails to dim their headlights, look toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and allow you to see enough of the road to stay on course. Do not try to retaliate by keeping your bright lights on.

questions.question: You are entering a freeway. Check traffic on the freeway by:
questions.answerA: Using your rearview and side mirrors.
questions.answerB: Using your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Using your side mirror and looking over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: When entering any roadway, you must be aware of traffic conditions. Use your side mirror and look over your shoulder to help you see and anticipate traffic when entering a freeway.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: One-way.
questions.answerC: Cattle crossing.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers turning left at a green light must yield to oncoming traffic and may complete the turn when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Work zone barriers, drums, cones, and signs are used to:
questions.answerA: Make drivers angry about slow traffic.
questions.answerB: Inconvenience drivers.
questions.answerC: Keep traffic out of hazardous work zones.
questions.explanation: Work zones on highways have become increasingly dangerous places for both workers and drivers. When approaching a work zone, watch for materials such as cones, barrels, signs, large vehicles, and workers in brightly colored vests to warn you and direct you.

questions.question: Before turning, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn the wheel.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: To complete a turn safely, you should activate your turn signal three to four seconds before your turn.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: You must turn left ahead.
questions.answerC: Do not enter.
questions.explanation: This signs warns that a four-way intersection is ahead.

questions.question: While driving on a two-lane road without bicycle lanes, you encounter a bicyclist traveling in the same direction. What is the safest way to pass the bicyclist?
questions.answerA: Slow down and wait until there is no traffic approaching, then pass the bicyclist while leaving him or her sufficient space.
questions.answerB: Continue driving straight. It is the bicyclist’s responsibility to get out of your way.
questions.answerC: Do not pass the bicyclist until you come to a traffic signal or stop sign.
questions.answerD: Honk at the bicyclist to let him or her know you are about to pass.
questions.explanation: You should pass a bicyclist the same way you would pass any other vehicle, but not so fast or close to them that you throw debris in their face or blow them around with the draft of air from your vehicle. Allow at least 3 feet of space between your side mirror and the bicyclist, or at least 5 feet on higher speed roads or when there is a group of bicyclists. Honking unnecessarily may startle riders and make them more likely to crash.

questions.question: A flashing red traffic light at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: Stop and wait for the green light.
questions.answerB: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Stop and yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: If you approach a flashing red light, treat it the same as you would a stop sign. Come to a complete stop, yield the right-of-way when necessary, and proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Don't drink if you are going to drive.
questions.answerB: Slippery when wet.
questions.answerC: Road curves ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the road is slippery when wet.

questions.question: If you approach a stopped school bus that has its lights flashing and signal arm extended, you should:
questions.answerB: Proceed at 15 mph if no children are present.
questions.answerC: Proceed at normal speed, but watch for children.
questions.explanation: If you approach a stopped school bus that has its lights flashing and arm extended, you must come to a full stop and remain stopped until the signal arm is pulled back and the bus resumes motion. This law applies whether you are traveling in the same direction as the bus or if you are approaching from the opposite side of the street.

questions.question: Signs with orange backgrounds are:
questions.answerB: Construction and maintenance warning signs.
questions.answerC: Regulatory signs.
questions.explanation: The color orange is used only for construction and maintenance warning signs.

questions.question: This white sign means:
questions.answerA: The railroad crossing is controlled. Continue at your regular speed.
questions.answerB: Look, listen, and prepare to stop at the crossing if necessary.
questions.answerC: Stop at the railroad tracks and wait for a signal before crossing.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing, you must look, listen, slow down, and prepare to stop. Let any trains pass before you proceed.

questions.question: If you are driving near a large commercial vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Follow the large vehicle closely to reduce wind drag on your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Avoid driving beside it for long stretches of time.
questions.answerC: Drive on its right side when on curves and hills.
questions.explanation: Because large commercial vehicles have large blind spots on each side, you should avoid driving beside them for long periods of time.

questions.question: At a light rail intersection, always:
questions.answerA: Look both ways before crossing tracks.
questions.answerB: Pay attention and obey all traffic signals.
questions.answerC: Share the road with pedestrians and bicyclists.
questions.explanation: You should never drive around lowered crossing gates. Always look both ways before turning across train tracks and always obey signs and traffic signals. Trains share the road with motor vehicles and bicyclists.

questions.question: Smoking and preparing to smoke while driving:
questions.answerB: Help maintain driver alertness.
questions.answerC: Are distracting activities.
questions.explanation: Smoking while driving can create dangerous distractions by causing you to take your hands off the wheel and/or your eyes off the road.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Merging traffic.
questions.answerC: Steep hill ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers of an upcoming steep hill. Drivers should adjust their speed accordingly to avoid collisions and brake damage.

questions.question: The faster the speed of your vehicle, the longer it takes to stop when you must react to other drivers' unexpected movements.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: The faster you are driving, the longer it will take for you to stop to react to other drivers' unexpected moves.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should return to your original lane when:
questions.answerA: You can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: You have cleared the front bumper of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerC: You are 50 feet in front of the passed vehicle.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle, move back into your original lane only when you can see the passed vehicle’s headlights in your rearview mirror. This ensures that you will have enough room to safely pull back in front of the other vehicle.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Steep grade ahead.
questions.answerC: Winding road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a steep downhill grade is ahead.

questions.question: This sign tells you that:
questions.answerA: No turns are allowed on this road.
questions.answerB: The road narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: There are a series of curves ahead.
questions.answerD: The road may be slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of an upcoming winding road with three or more curves.

questions.question: It is very foggy. You should slow down and:
questions.answerB: Turn your lights to their high beam setting.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights to their low beam setting.
questions.explanation: Use your low beams when driving in fog, snow, rain, or mist. Light from high beams will reflect off of precipitation, causing a glare and making it even more difficult to see. Some vehicles are equipped with fog lights that should be used in addition to low beam headlights.

questions.question: Because there is often slow-moving traffic on county highways, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in the left lane and drive above the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Be ready to adjust your speed to the speed of traffic.
questions.answerC: Pass slow-moving vehicles when in a curve.
questions.explanation: By looking well ahead of your vehicle, you will be able to spot slow-moving vehicles early and will have time to change lanes or slow down safely upon approaching them. Always be ready to adjust your speed to the speed of traffic, within the legal speed limit.

questions.question: If it feels like your tires have lost contact with the surface of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down by shifting into a lower gear.
questions.answerB: Ease your foot off the gas pedal.
questions.answerC: Slow down by pumping the brakes quickly and firmly.
questions.explanation: If it feels like your tires have lost contact with the surface of the road, you should ease your foot off the gas pedal and stay off the brakes. Do not try to stop or turn until your tires are gripping the road again.

questions.question: Who must yield when a driver is turning and a pedestrian is crossing without a traffic light?
questions.answerB: The driver
questions.answerC: Whoever is slower
questions.explanation: Drivers must yield to pedestrians when they are crossing at any intersection without a traffic light, whether or not there is a crosswalk.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot.
questions.answerB: Change lanes abruptly or spontaneously.
questions.answerC: Check for other vehicles moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, you must be sure that there are no vehicles in the space you want to enter. Check for other vehicles behind and to the side of your vehicle by checking your mirrors and blind spots. Always use the proper turn signal before changing lanes to allow surrounding vehicles time to react to your movements.

questions.question: When a pedestrian guided by a dog or carrying a white cane is crossing the street:
questions.answerA: You must always yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: You must tell them where to cross the street.
questions.answerC: You only have to yield the right-of-way if you are at a corner.
questions.explanation: Blind or partially blind pedestrians may carry a white cane or use the assistance of a guide dog. You must always yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian who is using a guide dog or carrying a white cane.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers that:
questions.answerA: The right lane is ending and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerB: The road curves ahead.
questions.answerC: There are upcoming intersections.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers that the number of lanes is reduced ahead and that traffic should merge left.

questions.question: Using a cell phone while operating a motor vehicle is considered a distraction because:
questions.answerA: It causes the driver to be concerned about the cost of the call.
questions.answerB: It occupies the driver's hands, eyes, and mind.
questions.answerC: It is an activity that draws the attention of other drivers.
questions.explanation: Using a cell phone while driving is dangerous because it occupies the user's eyes, hands, and mind. Even the most skilled drivers increase their risk of being involved in a crash by using a cell phone on the road.

questions.question: When turning left at an intersection:
questions.answerA: You should always yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic and pedestrians should yield to you.
questions.answerC: You should never yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.explanation: Drivers making left turns must yield to oncoming traffic that is traveling straight. Drivers must always yield to pedestrians.

questions.question: What happens if you drink alcohol while taking prescription or over-the-counter medicine?
questions.answerA: The medicine reduces the effect of the alcohol.
questions.answerB: The alcohol will help the medicine cure a cold.
questions.answerC: The combination could multiply the effects of the alcohol or medicine.
questions.answerD: There is no effect because they are different substances.
questions.explanation: Consuming alcohol and other drugs together can increase the impairing effects of both. For example, having one drink while you are also using a cold remedy could affect you as much as several drinks would when being consumed separately from any medications.

questions.question: What is the only medically proven method of removing alcohol or other drug combinations from your system?
questions.answerB: Give your body time.
questions.answerC: Drink coffee.
questions.explanation: Alcohol takes effect quickly and is slow to leave your system. Cold showers, black coffee, and exercise will do nothing to reduce a person's blood alcohol content (BAC). The only way to lower your BAC is to wait.

questions.question: You can help keep the driver behind you a safe distance away from your vehicle by:
questions.answerA: Driving 10 mph faster than the car behind you.
