questions.answerB: Driving 10 mph slower than the car behind you.
questions.answerC: Maintaining a steady speed.
questions.explanation: It is not always easy to maintain a safe distance behind your vehicle. However, you can help keep the driver behind you a safe distance away from your vehicle by maintaining a steady speed and signaling turns, lane changes, and deceleration in advance.

questions.question: Before changing lanes or attempting to pass another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Check your blind spots and mirrors.
questions.answerB: Signal your intention before changing lanes.
questions.answerC: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Every time you want to change lanes or otherwise move your vehicle to the right or left, signal to alert other drivers to your intentions. Always check your mirrors and turn your head to check your blind spot before attempting any lateral move.

questions.question: When entering the interstate, check for a gap in traffic in the nearest lane, adjust your speed to match traffic, signal, and:
questions.answerA: Expect traffic to allow you to proceed into the lane, since you have the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Merge carefully into the gap.
questions.answerC: Wait for the lane to clear before merging.
questions.explanation: Before merging into interstate traffic, you should identify a gap, accelerate to the speed of traffic, and signal. Merge into the gap when it is safe to do so. Be alert to other traffic and do not expect other drivers to clear the lane.

questions.question: Your brake lights tell other drivers that you:
questions.answerB: Have your emergency brake on.
questions.answerC: Are changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's brake lights indicate to other drivers that you are slowing down or stopping. Your brake lights should always be in working order when you are driving on any roadway.

questions.question: When driving on wet pavement, it's important to remember:
questions.answerA: That pavement is especially slippery right after it starts to rain.
questions.answerB: That wet roads can cause hydroplaning.
questions.answerC: To give yourself additional space when coming to a stop.
questions.explanation: Wet roadway surfaces can be dangerously slick, especially immediately following a rainfall. When you are driving on wet roads, your vehicle is traveling on a thin layer of oil, dirt, and water. Slow down when there is heavy rain, standing water, or slush on the road to reduce the risk of your wheels losing traction on the slick surface.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Right lane ends ahead.
questions.answerC: Watch for vehicles entering from the side.
questions.explanation: This sign directs traffic to the right of an island or barrier. The road ahead is divided.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true?
questions.answerA: A two-second following distance may be sufficient under normal conditions for an experienced driver.
questions.answerB: An inexperienced driver should maintain at least a three-second following distance under normal driving conditions.
questions.answerC: At speeds of 40 mph or faster, a four- to five-second following distance is recommended.
questions.explanation: When driving under ideal conditions at speeds slower than 40 mph, experienced drivers should maintain a following distance of at least two seconds. An inexperienced driver should maintain a following distance of at least three seconds. When driving under ideal conditions at speeds above 40 mph, drivers should increase their following distance to four or five seconds. Increase your following distance when anything makes conditions less than ideal.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about driving on a wet roadway?
questions.answerA: As you drive faster, your tires become less effective.
questions.answerB: Water does not affect cars with good tires.
questions.answerC: Deep water is less dangerous than shallow water.
questions.answerD: As you decrease your speed, the roadway becomes more slippery.
questions.explanation: The faster you drive on a wet roadway, the less effective your tires will be at wiping the water from the road. If your speed becomes excessive enough, your tires will lose their grip on the road entirely and you will begin to hydroplane (that is, to slide down the road on a film of water).

questions.question: How can you lower the risk of hydroplaning?
questions.answerA: Do not speed when the roads are wet.
questions.answerB: Use tires with proper air pressure.
questions.answerC: Replace tires with bad tread.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning happens when a vehicle glides on top of a thin layer of water between its tires and the road. Tires with low air pressure or bad tread can increase the risk of hydroplaning. Speeding also increases the risk.

questions.question: When driving at night on a dimly lit street, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive slowly enough that you can stop within the area illuminated by your headlights.
questions.answerB: Turn on your high beam headlights to better see the vehicles ahead of you.
questions.answerC: Keep the instrument panel lights bright to be more visible to other drivers.
questions.explanation: You should drive more slowly at night than during the day because it is not possible to see as far ahead at night. You should make sure that you can stop within the area illuminated by your headlights.

questions.question: When being passed by another vehicle:
questions.answerB: Maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.explanation: When being passed, you must yield to the passing vehicle and not increase your speed. Allow the vehicle to safely merge back into your lane.

questions.question: Which is the correct sequence of events as a school bus driver prepares to stop to load or unload children?
questions.answerA: Amber lights flash at the top of the bus, the bus stops as red lights flash, a stop arm goes out, and the door opens for the school children.
questions.answerB: The bus driver activates red flashing lights at the top of the bus, then activates amber flashing lights when the children are unloaded or seated.
questions.answerC: A stop arm goes out, amber lights begin flashing, and the school bus stops to load or unload children.
questions.explanation: When you meet an oncoming school bus displaying flashing amber lights, you must slow to a speed no faster than 20 mph and be prepared to stop. If its red lights are flashing or if its stop arm is out, you must come to a complete stop at least 15 feet from the bus. Remain stopped as long as the red lights flash or the stop arm is out.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Cross the centerline in an intersection.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spots by looking over your left or right shoulder.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check for drivers trying to pass you who may be trying to enter the same lane as you. Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. You should never attempt to pass or otherwise change lanes in an intersection.

questions.question: Which of the following road surfaces freezes first?
questions.answerB: An intersection
questions.answerC: A bridge
questions.explanation: Pavement on bridges and overpasses can become icy even when other surrounding pavement is dry. Bridges often freeze before, and thaw out after, the rest of a road.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You must travel through the intersection at the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: The maximum speed limit under ideal conditions is 55 mph.
questions.answerC: You must not travel below the speed indicated.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs provide notice to road users of traffic laws that must be obeyed. This particular sign tells you the maximum speed limit for the stretch of highway where it is posted. You may drive more slowly than the posted speed limit, based on road conditions, but it is illegal to drive any faster than the posted speed limit.

questions.question: When meeting a car with blinding headlights, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your bright lights until the other vehicle dims theirs.
questions.answerB: Flash your lights on and off to warn the other driver.
questions.answerC: Dim your lights and then speed up to pass quickly.
questions.answerD: Look toward the right side of the road.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle comes toward you with its high beams on, look away from the headlights and toward the right side of the road until the car has passed. This will keep you from being blinded.

questions.question: The proper way to make a right turn is to:
questions.answerA: Signal, slow down, and get into the lane closest to the centerline before turning.
questions.answerB: Signal, slow down, and get into the lane closest to the right curb before turning.
questions.answerC: Approach the corner in the lane nearest the right curb, but move over toward the middle of the street before turning.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a right turn, use the appropriate signal to give surrounding drivers adequate notice of your intentions. Slow down and approach the intersection from the right lane, staying as close as is practical to the right curb or edge of the roadway.

questions.question: Adjust your rearview and side mirrors:
questions.answerB: Whenever you need to use them.
questions.answerC: Before you get into the car.
questions.explanation: Your safety and the safety of other drivers and pedestrians depends a lot on what you do before driving. Before moving your vehicle, you should adjust your seat, adjust your mirrors, fasten your safety belt, and secure items in and on your vehicle. Do not wait until your vehicle is moving to adjust your mirrors.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway starts.
questions.answerC: Divided highway ends.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that the divided highway ends ahead. Prepare to change lanes or shift lane position.

questions.question: You are driving on a city street and see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights behind you. What should you do?
questions.answerA: Drive to the right edge of the road and slow down.
questions.answerB: Drive to the right edge of the road and stop.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane, slow down, and let it pass.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to any emergency vehicle that is using its siren and lights. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle has passed. If you are within an intersection, drive through the intersection first and then stop.

questions.question: A fully loaded tractor-trailer traveling at 55 mph could take up to ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: 125 feet
questions.answerC: 400 feet
questions.explanation: Tractor-trailers take longer distances to stop than smaller cars traveling at the same speed. A fully loaded tractor-trailer may take almost 400 feet to come to a complete stop when driving at 55 mph.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerB: Loose gravel
questions.answerC: Slippery when wet
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road may be slippery when wet. Exercise caution when driving on a slippery road.

questions.question: You are driving on a busy street and your vehicle’s accelerator sticks open. You should:
questions.answerB: Slam on your brakes.
questions.answerC: Turn on your four-way flashers.
questions.answerD: Turn off your ignition, taking care not to engage the steering wheel locking mechanism.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle’s accelerator sticks open, your vehicle will continue to maintain its speed or accelerate, even if you remove your foot from the gas pedal. Turn off the ignition, using care to move the ignition switch only far enough to stop the engine and not engage the steering wheel locking mechanism. Apply your brakes and move off the road to a safe area.

questions.question: The driver's left arm and hand are extended upward. This hand signal means that the driver plans to:
questions.answerB: Turn right.
questions.answerC: Come to a stop.
questions.explanation: If a driver's left arm and hand are extended upward, they are indicating that they intend to turn right. Adjust your driving accordingly if following a driver who is using this hand signal.

questions.question: When driving in traffic, it is safest to:
questions.answerA: Fluctuate your speed to keep alert.
questions.answerB: Drive faster than the flow of traffic.
questions.answerC: Drive slower than the flow of traffic.
questions.answerD: Drive with the flow of traffic.
questions.explanation: Crashes often happen when some drivers go faster or slower than other vehicles on the road. Always try to drive with the flow of traffic, within the posted speed limit.

questions.question: If you are driving in another driver's blind spot, you should:
questions.answerA: Move forward or drop back so the other driver can see you.
questions.answerB: Keep a steady pace.
questions.answerC: Stay in the driver's blind spot.
questions.answerD: Honk to let them know you are there.
questions.explanation: Do not drive in someone else’s blind spot. Move forward or drop back so that the other driver can see you.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlights when driving in fog. High beams will reflect back at the driver and lower visibility.

questions.question: Double solid yellow lane markings mean that:
questions.answerB: Both lanes may pass.
questions.answerC: The lane to the right may pass.
questions.explanation: Yellow lane markings indicate a separation of lanes where traffic is traveling in opposite directions. When you see double solid yellow lane markings, passing is prohibited from both directions.

questions.question: Distracted drivers are at a greater risk of a crash when they are using which of the following?
questions.answerB: Radio
questions.answerC: Cell phone
questions.explanation: Using a cell phone (including a hands-free phone) or any kind of audio device (including a radio or CD player) can be a dangerous distraction and contributes to the risk of a crash.

questions.question: If a motorist sees pedestrians in an upcoming crosswalk, what should the motorist do?
questions.answerA: Continue ahead. The motorist has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Wait for the pedestrians to cross the street.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right and go around the pedestrians.
questions.explanation: A driver must yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian within a crosswalk. The driver should wait until the intersection is clear to proceed.

questions.question: This bicyclist is signaling:
questions.answerB: An upcoming stop.
questions.answerC: A right turn.
questions.explanation: Bicycles do not have turn signals so bicyclists use hand and arm signals to alert other drivers to their intentions. If a bicyclist puts their left arm straight out, they are signaling that they intend to turn left.

questions.question: What kinds of drugs can affect your driving ability?
questions.answerB: Marijuana
questions.answerC: Cold remedies
questions.explanation: Many kinds of drugs can impair your ability to drive. This includes illegal drugs and legal prescription or over-the-counter medications. It can be a criminal offense to drive while impaired by any drug.

questions.question: If you are continually being passed on the right and the left while driving in the center lane of an expressway, you should:
questions.answerB: Move to the lane on your right.
questions.answerC: Move to the lane on your left.
questions.explanation: If a road has four or more lanes with two-way traffic, drive in the right lanes unless you are passing or turning left. If you are on an interstate highway and are driving below the speed of the flow of traffic, use the right lane.

questions.question: After being pulled over by law enforcement, a driver should immediately exit the vehicle and quickly approach the officer’s squad car.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: If stopped by law enforcement, you should stay in your vehicle with both hands clearly in sight on the steering wheel.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop and yield to pedestrians and cross traffic.
questions.answerB: Stop and immediately proceed.
questions.answerC: Slow down and be prepared to stop.
questions.explanation: Come to a full stop at an intersection controlled by this sign. Stop at the marked stop line or before entering the crosswalk or intersection. Let other vehicles or pedestrians pass if they are in your path, then proceed.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway begins.
questions.answerC: Lane ends.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the right lane ends ahead. A merging maneuver will be required for drivers in that lane.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop, if necessary.
questions.answerC: You must come to a complete stop.
questions.answerD: Drive with caution and be ready to stop.
questions.explanation: An eight-sided sign always means "stop." You must come to a complete stop and wait for any vehicles or pedestrians to clear the way before proceeding.

questions.question: Increase your following distance when driving behind a large vehicle:
questions.answerA: To better see around the sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Because other drivers tend to pull behind large vehicles before trying to pass them.
questions.answerC: Because following too closely will get you caught in the vehicle's slipstream.
questions.explanation: Drivers of trucks, buses, vans, and any vehicles pulling campers or trailers may not be able to see you if you are driving directly behind them. Increase your following distance when driving behind one of these vehicles. Additionally, large vehicles can block your view of the road, so increase your following distance to look around the sides of the vehicle and see the road ahead.

questions.question: When driving at night, using only your parking lights is unlawful.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: It is unlawful to drive at night using only your parking lights. Drivers are required to use their headlights when driving in the dark.

questions.question: When approaching a person who is crossing the street while using a white cane or guide dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the person is well away from your path of travel.
questions.answerB: Honk your horn as you proceed past them.
questions.answerC: Carefully drive around them.
questions.explanation: When approaching a pedestrian who is using a white cane or guide dog while crossing the street, you must stop until the person is well away from your path of travel. Always yield the right-of-way to blind pedestrians.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your parking lights.
questions.answerC: Use your low beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Drivers should use low beam headlights when driving in fog. High beams will reflect back at the driver, making it difficult to see.

questions.question: You should always travel:
questions.answerA: At the speed of vehicles surrounding you.
questions.answerB: At the speed limit.
questions.answerC: At a speed appropriate for road and weather conditions.
questions.explanation: The speed at which you should drive your vehicle depends on road conditions, the weather, and the legal speed limit. You may never drive above the legal speed limit. Decrease your speed when anything makes conditions less than ideal.

questions.question: Talking or texting on a cell phone while driving will not significantly increase your chances being involved in a crash.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Using a phone while driving is a distraction that increases your risk of being involved in a crash.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Multiple turns.
questions.answerC: Lane shifting.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to potential traffic merging from the right. Drivers should prepare to allow the traffic to merge safely.

questions.question: What do speed limit signs indicate?
questions.answerA: Potential driving speeds for the area
questions.answerB: The maximum or minimum speed that is legally allowed to be driven
questions.answerC: The speed drivers should drive in heavy traffic
questions.answerD: The speed drivers should drive under poor conditions
questions.explanation: Speed limit signs indicate the maximum or minimum safe speed that is allowed to be driven on a roadway. The maximum limits are for ideal conditions and you must reduce your speed when conditions require it.

questions.question: You have the right-of-way when turning left on which of the following traffic signals?
questions.answerB: A flashing yellow light
questions.answerC: A green arrow pointing left
questions.explanation: A green steady arrow means you may pass through the intersection in the direction that the arrow is pointing. Oncoming traffic is required to stop for turning traffic.

questions.question: Cell phones can be a serious source of driver distractions.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When on the road, drivers should not use cell phones, computers, or other distracting devices, except to report a crash or emergency. Your full attention should be devoted to driving.

questions.question: Roads become very slippery:
questions.answerA: When it has been raining for an hour or more.
questions.answerB: The day after it rains.
questions.answerC: For the first 10 to 15 minutes of a rainstorm.
questions.answerD: Right after the rain has stopped.
questions.explanation: Pavement can become very slippery within the first 10 to 15 minutes of a rainstorm because the rain causes oil in the asphalt to rise to the surface of the road. This problem becomes even worse in hot weather. The heat combined with the water causes more oil to rise to the road surface.

questions.question: If the gates at a railroad crossing are down and red lights are flashing, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop and proceed only when the gates are raised and the lights have stopped flashing.
questions.answerB: Drive around the gates after stopping.
questions.answerC: Drive side by side with the train.
questions.explanation: Stop at a railroad crossing when the warning lights start to flash and the gate lowers. Remain stopped until the gate is raised and the lights stop flashing. Never drive around lowered gates at a railroad crossing because it is against the law and very dangerous.

questions.question: To check your blind spot when changing lanes to the left, you should glance:
questions.answerB: At your side mirror.
questions.answerC: Over your left shoulder.
questions.explanation: To check your blind spot, glance over your shoulder in the direction that you want to move.

questions.question: Yellow lines separate:
questions.answerB: Traffic moving in opposite directions on two-way roads.
questions.answerC: All carpool lanes from regular traffic lanes.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines mark the center of a road used for two-way traffic. A solid yellow centerline indicates that drivers may not cross the line to pass. A broken yellow centerline indicates that drivers may cross the line to pass, but only if passing would not interfere with traffic.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: Signal at least 100 feet before changing lanes to pass and ensure there is no oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors and look over your left shoulder to check your blind spot when passing to the left.
questions.answerC: When passing, wait until you can see both headlights of the passed car in your rearview mirror before returning to your original lane.
questions.explanation: When passing, you must always signal at least 100 feet in advance of your lane change. Always check behind you in your mirrors and look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. Wait until you can see both headlights of the passed car in your rearview mirror before returning to your original lane.

questions.question: Blind spots are:
questions.answerA: Spots in your vision when you become fatigued.
questions.answerB: Areas of the road that cannot be seen in a vehicle's mirrors.
questions.answerC: Traffic control devices.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move. Check for obstructions near the rear corners of your vehicle. These areas are called “blind spots” because you cannot see them by using your mirrors.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits drivers from making a U-turn. You cannot turn around to go in the opposite direction at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: If you want to pass a pedestrian who is walking along the roadway and an oncoming vehicle is approaching, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and let the oncoming vehicle pass before you pass the pedestrian.
questions.answerB: Keep driving at a steady speed. The oncoming vehicle must stop for you.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn to get the pedestrian to move over.
questions.explanation: If possible, try to only deal with one roadway hazard at a time. If you want to pass a pedestrian but an oncoming vehicle is approaching, slow down and let the vehicle pass. You may then pass the pedestrian if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: At an intersection with a yield sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop before entering the intersection.
questions.answerB: Yield just to the traffic on the right.
questions.answerC: Yield just to the traffic on the left.
questions.answerD: Slow down and yield the right-of-way to other traffic.
questions.explanation: A yield sign means that you must slow down and yield the right-of-way to traffic in the intersection or roadway you are entering.

questions.question: On slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive more quickly.
questions.answerC: Drive the speed limit, with caution.
questions.answerD: Not drive more quickly than 20 mph.
questions.explanation: You should slow down at the first sign of rain, snow, or sleet, all of which can create slippery road conditions. When conditions on the road are less than ideal, safety may require that you drive more slowly than the posted speed limit.

questions.question: A driver should:
questions.answerA: Stare directly in front of their car.
questions.answerB: Only focus on the middle of the road.
questions.answerC: Watch beside, ahead, and to the rear of their car.
questions.explanation: A driver should watch beside, ahead, and to the rear of their car. To be a good driver, you must know what is happening all around your vehicle.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop if necessary.
questions.answerC: You must come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: An octagonal sign always means stop. When approaching a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop at the marked stop line and proceed only when it is safe to do so. If there is no stop line, stop before the crosswalk. If there is no crosswalk, stop before the intersection at a point from which you can see oncoming traffic.

questions.question: You should be cautious when passing a bicycle because:
questions.answerA: You are moving faster than the bicycle.
questions.answerB: The bicycle always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Oncoming traffic may not see you pull out to pass the bicycle.
questions.answerD: The cyclist may have to swerve into traffic to avoid an object on the road.
questions.explanation: You should always be cautious when passing a bicycle because the cyclist may have to swerve into traffic to avoid an object on the road. Always be particularly careful when driving near bicyclists.

questions.question: If the rear of your vehicle is skidding to the left, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn your steering wheel to the left to correct the skid.
questions.answerC: Turn your steering wheel to the right to correct the skid.
questions.explanation: If you begin to skid on a wet or icy road, take your foot off the accelerator, stay off the brakes, and turn your steering wheel in the direction of the skid. However, if you have anti-lock brakes, you should apply your brakes firmly and steer straight ahead.

questions.question: If you are turning onto a street with more than one lane traveling in your direction, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn into the lane closest to your previous lane.
questions.answerB: Turn into the lane marked with an arrow.
questions.answerC: Turn into the middle lane.
questions.explanation: When turning onto a street with more than one lane moving in the direction that you are traveling, turn into the lane that is closest to your previous lane. Do not change lanes when turning.

questions.question: At dawn or dusk and in rain or snow, it can be hard to see and be seen. A good way to let other drivers know you are there is to turn:
questions.answerB: On your parking lights.
questions.answerC: On your headlights.
questions.explanation: You must use your headlights at any time when conditions prevent you from seeing other vehicles and when it may be difficult for other drivers to see you. Always use your low beam headlights if weather conditions require you to use your windshield wipers.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Uncontrolled intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Four-way stop ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a traffic signal is ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No outlet.
questions.answerC: No U-turns.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that U-turns are prohibited. You may see a sign like this at an intersection that commonly has oncoming traffic.

questions.question: This yellow sign means:
questions.answerB: Merging traffic ahead.
questions.answerC: Lane ends ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of the possible presence of merging traffic.

questions.question: Your body gets rid of approximately:
questions.answerB: One alcoholic drink an hour.
questions.answerC: Two alcoholic drinks an hour.
questions.explanation: The average person’s body will process about one alcoholic drink in one hour. However, many factors play a part in determining how impaired a person will become when consuming alcohol, including the amount of alcohol consumed, how fast it is consumed, and a person’s body weight, food intake, and general health.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: School zone.
questions.explanation: A round yellow sign indicates that there is a railroad crossing ahead.

questions.question: An orange-colored sign like this means:
questions.answerB: You must change lanes ahead.
questions.answerC: There is a detour ahead.
questions.explanation: Orange-colored signs indicate construction areas. Proceed with caution.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about large trucks?
questions.answerA: They take longer to stop than passenger vehicles.
questions.answerB: They all have air brakes that allow them to stop quickly.
questions.answerC: They are more maneuverable than passenger vehicles.
questions.explanation: Large trucks take longer to stop than other vehicles traveling at the same speed. The average passenger vehicle traveling at 55 mph can stop within 400 feet. However, a large truck traveling at the same speed can take almost 800 feet to stop.

questions.question: Backing your vehicle is:
questions.answerB: Dangerous if you have a helper.
questions.answerC: Only dangerous in large vehicles.
questions.explanation: Backing up is always dangerous because it is hard to see behind your vehicle. Use extra caution when backing up.

questions.question: If oncoming headlights are blinding you while you are driving at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Look toward the right edge of the road.
questions.answerB: Switch your lights to high beams.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights on and off.
questions.explanation: If the headlights of an oncoming vehicle are blinding, glance toward the right edge of the road instead of looking directly ahead. This should keep your vehicle safely on the road until you pass the oncoming vehicle.

questions.question: The best way to deal with tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Speed up to increase the distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerB: Slam on your brakes to get the other driver to back off.
questions.answerC: Change lanes or gradually slow down to encourage them to pass.
questions.explanation: Check the traffic behind you several times a minute to know if another driver is tailgating, approaching too fast, or trying to pass. If another car is following you too closely, slow down and let it pass. Most rear-end collisions are caused by vehicles following too closely.

questions.question: If your car starts to skid, turn your steering wheel:
questions.answerA: To keep the front wheels straight.
questions.answerB: In the direction you want the vehicle to go.
questions.answerC: In the opposite direction of the skid.
questions.answerD: In any direction. It doesn't matter.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle goes into a skid, you should turn the steering wheel in the direction you want the vehicle to go. As soon as the vehicle begins to straighten out, turn the steering wheel back the other way.

questions.question: When driving on an interstate:
questions.answerA: Stop on the shoulder of the road if you are tired.
questions.answerB: You should always use cruise control.
questions.answerC: Signal, check mirrors, and check blind spots before changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Signal, check your mirrors, and check your blind spot before changing lanes or passing on an interstate. Only stop on the shoulder of the interstate in the case of an emergency and change lanes as infrequently as possible. Cruise control should not be used in heavy traffic or under poor weather conditions.

questions.question: Excessive speed:
questions.answerA: Saves time so you can get to your destination more quickly.
questions.answerB: Helps you maneuver around obstacles.
questions.answerC: Increases the likelihood of serious bodily injury and death.
questions.explanation: Excessive speed is one of the most common contributing factors to vehicle crashes. Excessive speed does not save time and often leads to high-risk decision-making.

questions.question: When should you yield your legal right-of-way?
questions.answerB: Whenever it helps prevent collisions.
questions.answerC: Never. It confuses other drivers.
questions.explanation: Never assume other drivers will give you the right-of-way. Yield your right-of-way whenever it helps prevent collisions.

questions.question: The driver's left arm and hand are extended downward. This hand signal means that the driver plans to:
questions.answerB: Turn right.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: If a driver's left arm and hand are extended downward, they are indicating that they intend to stop. Adjust your driving accordingly if following a driver who is using this hand signal.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Highway changes ahead and to the right.
questions.answerB: Hiking trails ahead and to the right.
questions.answerC: Hotel ahead and to the right.
questions.answerD: Hospital ahead and to the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that hospital emergency services are located to the right.

questions.question: When driving in fog:
questions.answerB: Use your low beams.
questions.answerC: Use your high beams.
questions.answerD: It makes no difference which lights you use.
questions.explanation: You should use low beam headlights when driving in fog, rain, or snow.

questions.question: When the road is marked with a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line, with the broken line next to your lane, you may pass:
questions.answerB: If you are on an expressway.
questions.answerC: If traffic is clear.
questions.explanation: When there is a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line in the center of the road and the broken line is next to your lane, you may cross the lines to pass if there is no oncoming traffic.

questions.question: When you are merging onto the freeway, you should be driving:
questions.answerA: At or near the speed of traffic on the freeway.
questions.answerB: Five to 10 mph slower than the speed of traffic on the freeway.
questions.answerC: The posted speed limit for freeway traffic.
questions.explanation: When merging onto a freeway, you should enter at or near the speed of traffic.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerB: Begin signaling as you move into the next lane.
questions.answerC: Signal at least 500 feet before your lane change when driving on residential streets.
questions.explanation: Other cars and motorcycles are often hidden in a vehicle’s blind spot, so be sure to glance over your shoulder before you begin a lane change. Begin signaling 100 feet before changing lanes or turning in a residential area. Signal five seconds in advance when changing lanes on a freeway.

questions.question: A regulatory sign containing a red circle with a slash through the middle indicates:
questions.answerA: That drivers should come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: That an action is forbidden.
questions.answerC: That some drivers should yield to other drivers.
questions.answerD: That drivers should drive under the speed limit.
questions.explanation: Some regulatory signs prohibit certain actions. These signs are rectangular and white with red and black markings. A red circle and slash on top of a black symbol indicates that the specified action is forbidden.

questions.question: To avoid panic stops:
questions.answerA: Watch for hazards well ahead of you on the roadway.
questions.answerB: Drive with your window partly down.
questions.answerC: Accelerate heavily.
questions.explanation: Try to avoid panic stops by watching well ahead of your vehicle for hazards. If you allow yourself space to react to hazards, you are less likely to need to stop or turn suddenly.

questions.question: As alcohol builds up in your blood, it:
questions.answerB: Makes you feel less confident.
questions.answerC: Begins to metabolize itself more quickly.
questions.answerD: Decreases the number of driving errors.
questions.explanation: As alcohol builds up in your system, it will slow your reactions, make you feel more confident, and cause you to make more errors.

questions.question: The effect that lack of sleep has on your safe driving ability is the same as:
questions.answerB: The effect that amphetamines have.
questions.answerC: The effect that anger has.
questions.answerD: The effect that driving with teenagers has.
questions.explanation: Fatigue and being under the influence of alcohol have similar effects on your ability to drive safely. For example, being awake for 18 hours impairs your driving about as much as a blood alcohol level of 0.05 percent. Being awake for 24 hours in a row has the same effect on your driving as a blood alcohol level of 0.10 percent.

questions.question: Downward-facing triangular signs:
questions.answerB: Tell drivers to yield.
questions.answerC: Indicate construction zones.
questions.explanation: Downward-facing triangular signs usually indicate that drivers should yield. Once the road is clear of traffic or pedestrians and it is safe to do so, drivers may proceed.

questions.question: When driving on the highway, consistently looking far ahead of your vehicle:
questions.answerA: Helps you keep up with traffic.
questions.answerB: Reduces the need for last-minute braking or turning.
questions.answerC: Allows you to spot upcoming police officers.
questions.explanation: To avoid the need for last-minute braking or turning, consistently watch the road far ahead of your vehicle. By looking ahead and being ready to stop or change lanes if needed, you can drive more safely, save fuel, and help keep traffic moving at a steady pace.

questions.question: You are driving on the freeway. The vehicle in front of you is a large truck. You should drive:
questions.answerA: Closely behind the truck in bad weather because the driver can see farther ahead than you can.
questions.answerB: Farther behind the truck than you would when following a passenger vehicle.
questions.answerC: No more than one car length behind the truck so the driver can see you.
questions.explanation: When you follow so closely behind a truck that you cannot see the truck driver’s side view mirrors, the trucker cannot see you and has no way of knowing you are there. Tailgating a truck, or any vehicle, is dangerous because you take away your own cushion of safety if the vehicle in front of you stops quickly.

questions.question: You approach an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing. You must:
questions.answerA: Slow down. If possible, change lanes so you will not drive next to the stopped emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Drive to the right side of the road and stop.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane and continue to drive at the same speed.
questions.answerD: Accelerate to quickly pass the stopped vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you approach an emergency vehicle, tow truck, or roadside assistance vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing, you must change lanes to allow the vehicle extra space. If there is only one lane moving in your direction, or if changing lanes would be unsafe, you must slow down to a speed below the posted speed limit and give the stationary vehicle as much room as possible. Always slow down and be prepared to stop when you approach an emergency scene.

questions.question: Always signal when:
questions.answerB: Pulling into or out of a parking space.
questions.answerC: Pulling into traffic from a parking area or alley.
questions.explanation: Your turn signals should always be used when you make any movement to the left or right. You should use your signal when pulling into traffic from a curbside parking space, moving into a new lane, or passing another vehicle.

questions.question: You are driving when your power steering stops working. You should:
questions.answerA: Honk your horn and turn off the ignition.
questions.answerB: Turn on your hazard lights and brace yourself.
questions.answerC: Work hard to steer, reduce your speed, drive to a safe area, and stop.
questions.explanation: If your power steering stops working, additional effort will be required to maintain steering control. Reduce your speed and pull off the roadway to stop in a safe area.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Road construction/maintenance area.
questions.answerC: Traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign is displayed on slow-moving vehicles.

questions.question: When two vehicles enter an intersection from different highways at the same time, which vehicle must yield the right-of-way?
questions.answerB: The vehicle on the left
questions.answerC: The vehicle on the right
questions.explanation: At intersections that are controlled by signs or signals and at intersections that are uncontrolled, the driver on the left must yield the right-of-way to the driver on the right when two vehicles arrive to the intersection at the same time.

questions.question: An intersection has no traffic signs or signals. You arrive at the same time as a vehicle to your right. You should:
questions.answerA: Speed up and get through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Slow down and yield to the vehicle on your right.
questions.answerC: Drive into the intersection and make the other vehicle stop.
questions.answerD: Honk your horn and drive through the intersection.
questions.explanation: When two vehicles arrive to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way. Once the vehicle on the right has safely passed through the intersection, the other driver may proceed.

questions.question: This yellow warning sign means:
questions.answerA: You are approaching a school or school crosswalk.
questions.answerB: Slow down, drive with caution, and watch for children.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: This sign is placed on roads near schools to warn drivers to slow down, drive with caution, and watch for children.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Winding road ahead.
questions.answerC: Reserved parking for persons with disabilities.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that two lanes of traffic going the same direction will soon merge into one lane.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: Do not pass:
questions.answerB: When school bus lights are flashing.
questions.answerC: When approaching an intersection.
questions.explanation: You should never pass if there is an oncoming vehicle in the passing lane, if your view is blocked by a curve or hill, at an intersection, before or on a railroad crossing or bridge, or in any other no passing zone. Unless you are on the opposite side of a multilane roadway with a median or shared center turn lane, you may not pass a stopped school bus that has its flashing red lights activated.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding seat belts and child restraints in vehicles?
questions.answerA: You should never place an infant or small child in the front seat of a vehicle with airbags.
questions.answerB: An airbag can be dangerous to an infant or small child, even in a low-speed collision.
questions.answerC: You should always make sure all your passengers are using a seat belt or child restraint.
questions.explanation: Before you drive, always fasten your seat belt and make sure all your passengers are using seat belts or child restraints. Studies have shown that if you use seat belts, your chances of being hurt or killed in a traffic crash are greatly reduced. Children age 12 and under should always ride properly restrained in a rear seat. Never put a rear-facing infant restraint in the front seat of a vehicle with a front passenger airbag.

questions.question: Roads freeze quickly when they are:
questions.answerB: Curvy.
questions.answerC: In the sun.
questions.explanation: In cold or wet weather, you should take special care on sections of road that are shaded by trees or buildings. These areas freeze more quickly than the rest of the road and are the last parts of the road to dry.

questions.question: A seat belt should be adjusted so that it:
questions.answerB: Is buckled snugly across your hip bones and lower abdomen.
questions.answerC: Is hidden beneath the seat.
questions.answerD: Keeps the seat belt buzzer or light from operating.
questions.explanation: Lap belts should fit snugly across your hip bones and the lower part of your abdomen. Shoulder belts should sit comfortably so that you can insert your fist between the belt and your chest.

questions.question: If your vehicle begins to skid, you should:
questions.answerA: Ease up on the gas pedal.
questions.answerB: Brake as hard as possible.
questions.answerC: Turn off the ignition.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, release the accelerator or brake pedal to regain vehicle balance. Steer in the direction of the skid to regain control of the vehicle.

questions.question: When driving in fog, it is best to drive with:
questions.answerB: Low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: Use your low beam headlights when driving in fog, rain, or snow. High beam lights can reflect off the weather conditions, lowering visibility even more.

questions.question: It is unlawful for a car to try to share a lane with a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Motorcycle operators have the right to use a complete traffic lane. Two motorcyclists may share a lane, but a car should never try to share a lane with a motorcycle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: No right turn.
questions.explanation: Where this sign is posted, it is prohibited to make a right turn. It would be unsafe and unlawful to make a right turn at an intersection with this sign.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Do not enter.
questions.answerC: No turn on red.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead. The road will split into two one-way roadways separated by a median or divider. You must keep to the right.

questions.question: If two vehicles arrive to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time:
questions.answerA: The largest vehicle has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The car on the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: The car on the left shall yield to the car on the right.
questions.answerD: The car on the right shall yield to the car on the left.
questions.explanation: If two vehicles arrive at the same time to an uncontrolled intersection, the driver on the left must yield to the driver on the right. The driver on the left may then proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Keep right.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign means that right turns are prohibited.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop only if other cars are approaching.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way to pedestrians.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. These signs alert drivers to areas where bicycles may be crossing.

questions.question: Construction zone signs are generally:
questions.answerA: Square or rectangular with white and red coloring.
questions.answerB: Round or octagonal with black and yellow coloring.
questions.answerC: Diamond-shaped or rectangular with orange and black coloring.
questions.explanation: All temporary signs in work zones have an orange background with black letters or symbols. These signs are found on the right side of the road, or on both the left and right sides if the roadway is a divided highway.

questions.question: If you parallel park facing downward on a hill:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels sharply toward the side of the road.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels away from the side of the road.
questions.answerC: Keep your wheels straight.
questions.explanation: When parking downhill, turn your front wheels toward the curb or edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road without a curb, turn your wheels toward the edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road with a curb, you must turn your front wheels away from the curb.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Pass the vehicle as slowly as possible.
questions.answerB: Drive at the same speed as the vehicle you are passing.
questions.answerC: Pass the vehicle as safely and as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle that is traveling in the same direction as you, pass quickly to resume visibility. Return to your previous lane only when you can see both of the vehicle's headlights in your rearview mirror.

questions.question: A red and white triangular sign at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: A triangular red and white yield sign means that you must decrease speed as you approach an intersection and yield the right-of-way to any vehicles or pedestrians in the intersection. You must be prepared to stop if conditions require it.

questions.question: You may drive across a dashed white line:
questions.answerB: Only during daylight hours.
questions.answerC: When it is safe to change lanes.
questions.explanation: Traffic lanes moving in the same direction are separated by broken white lines. You may cross over dashed lines to pass, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Your tire blows out while you are driving. You should:
questions.answerB: Hold your steering wheel tightly and slow to a stop.
questions.answerC: Keep driving normally.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and continue driving.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, do not immediately apply the brakes. Grip the steering wheel firmly and steer to remain in your traffic lane. Reduce your speed gradually by releasing the accelerator and staying off the brakes. Once you are moving very slowly, apply the brakes lightly and pull off the road into a safe area.

questions.question: This sign tells you that:
questions.answerA: No turns are allowed on the road.
questions.answerB: The road narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: There is a series of curves ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers about an upcoming winding road.

questions.question: A diamond-shaped sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop.
questions.answerC: Warning.
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs are used to warn drivers of special conditions or hazards ahead. They are typically yellow or orange in color.

questions.question: Only ____ can lower blood alcohol concentration (BAC) and reduce alcohol's effects on a body.
questions.answerB: Eating foods high in fat
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: The only way to sober up after drinking alcohol is to allow time for your body to eliminate the alcohol in your system. Nothing you can do, including eating and drinking, can accelerate this process.

questions.question: You are driving on a one-way street. You may only turn left onto another one-way street if:
questions.answerA: You increase your speed before the turn.
questions.answerB: Traffic on the street moves to the right.
questions.answerC: Traffic on the street moves to the left.
questions.explanation: You may turn left onto a one-way street that moves to the left if there is no sign prohibiting the turn. You may not turn left onto a one-way street where traffic moves to the right.

questions.question: You may park or stop along the shoulder of the freeway:
questions.answerA: As long as you turn on your four-way (emergency) flashers.
questions.answerB: If no part of your vehicle is on the road.
questions.answerC: If you need to look at a map for directions.
questions.answerD: Only if you have an emergency.
questions.explanation: It is prohibited to park on the shoulder of a freeway, except in an emergency.

questions.question: A red arrow displayed on a traffic light means that:
questions.answerA: A driver must proceed slowly through the intersection.
questions.answerB: A driver must stop and then proceed when the way is clear.
questions.answerC: A driver must stop and then proceed when the signal changes to a green light or green arrow.
questions.answerD: A driver may turn in the direction that the red arrow is pointing.
questions.explanation: Unless a posted sign indicates otherwise, a traffic signal displaying a red arrow means that drivers must come to a full stop and remain stopped until a green light or green arrow appears.

questions.question: On an undivided highway, if an emergency vehicle approaches while using its siren and flashing lights, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive slowly until it has passed.
questions.answerB: Speed up to clear traffic.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right and stop.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to a police vehicle, fire engine, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle using a siren or air horn and red or blue flashing lights. Pull over to the right edge of the road, or as near to the right side as possible, when you see or hear an emergency vehicle approaching from any direction on an undivided highway.

questions.question: From top to bottom, the following is the proper order for traffic lights:
questions.answerB: Red, green, yellow.
questions.answerC: Green, red, yellow.
questions.explanation: On a traffic signal arranged vertically, red is always on top and green on the bottom. When arranged horizontally, red is always on the left and green on the right.

questions.question: Orange is the color of signs used to communicate with drivers in construction work zones.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Most signs in work areas are orange and diamond-shaped, although some signs are rectangular. These signs and traffic control devices are commonly reflective to better attract your attention at night.

questions.question: You are borrowing an unfamiliar vehicle from a friend. You should:
questions.answerA: Not put too much thought into it because all vehicles are the same.
questions.answerB: Hide from your friend that you are unfamiliar with the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Disregard any obvious defects to avoid embarrassing your friend.
questions.answerD: Take a few minutes before driving to familiarize yourself with the operation and location of all the vehicle’s equipment.
questions.explanation: When driving an unfamiliar vehicle, take a few minutes before driving to familiarize yourself with the location and operation of the turn signals, hazard warning signals, headlights and beam selector, windshield wipers and washers, brakes, gear selector, and horn. Any defects should be corrected before the vehicle is driven.

questions.question: When you want to make a right turn, your car must be:
questions.answerA: Near the center of the street.
questions.answerB: Close to the left side of the street.
questions.answerC: Close to the right side of the street.
questions.answerD: Past the center of the intersection when you begin to turn.
questions.explanation: As you prepare to make a right turn, you should get as far to the right side of the road as possible. Do not cut across lanes of traffic to perform any turn.

questions.question: When entering the interstate on a short entrance ramp where there is no acceleration lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Immediately enter the far-right traffic lane on the interstate and speed up to match the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Use the shoulder of the main road to get up to the speed of traffic.
questions.answerC: Speed up and enter the interstate only after you have identified a gap in traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering the interstate on a short entrance ramp where there is no acceleration lane, speed up only after you have identified a gap in traffic. In general, you should be stopped while waiting for a gap to appear.

questions.question: Anything that requires you to ____ could cause you to crash.
questions.answerA: Take your eyes off the road
questions.answerB: Take your hands off the wheel
questions.answerC: Take your attention away from the task of driving
questions.explanation: Anything that causes you to take your attention away from driving, take your eyes off the road, and/or take your hands off the wheel is a distraction.

questions.question: You do not have to stop for a school bus that is stopped with its red lights flashing if it is on a private road.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When a school bus is stopped with its red lights flashing and stop arm out, other drivers are required to stop. This law applies to drivers traveling on both public and private roads.

questions.question: When approaching a stop sign that is not marked by a crosswalk, drivers should stop their vehicles before entering the intersection.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: At a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop at the stop line, if there is one. If there is no stop line, you must make a complete stop before entering the crosswalk. If there is no crosswalk, you must stop before entering the intersection.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: You must stop ahead.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not allowed.
questions.answerD: There is a traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a traffic signal ahead.

questions.question: It is necessary to use your low beams any time you are:
questions.answerB: On a freeway.
questions.answerC: In fog.
questions.explanation: Use your low beams when driving in fog, snow, rain, or mist. Light from high beams will reflect off of precipitation, causing a glare and making it even more difficult to see. Some vehicles are equipped with fog lights that should be used in addition to low beam headlights.

questions.question: If your car begins to skid out of control, you should:
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes lightly.
questions.answerC: Stay off the brakes.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, stay off the brakes. Continue to correct your steering until the vehicle is back under your control and moving safely down the road.

questions.question: This sign is used to prevent:
questions.answerB: Entrance to road construction areas.
questions.answerC: Entrance to dead-end streets.
questions.answerD: Entrances from the wrong direction on one-way streets and expressway ramps.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a road has one-way traffic and you must not enter from your current direction.

questions.question: When driving on roads that may be slippery:
questions.answerA: Always drive at the maximum speed limit.
questions.answerB: Use cruise control to maintain a steady speed.
questions.answerC: Reduce your following distance.
questions.answerD: Do not make any sudden changes in speed or direction.
questions.explanation: You should avoid making any sudden changes in speed or direction when driving on a slippery surface. Reduce your speed on slippery roads and do not use cruise control.

questions.question: To be safe when crossing a railroad, you should:
questions.answerA: Look both ways, but only when the red light is flashing.
questions.answerB: Listen, look both ways, and then proceed if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Cross especially quickly when a train is approaching.
questions.answerD: Quickly pass under any lowering gates.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings are always dangerous. Drivers should look and listen for an approaching train coming from either direction before proceeding across the tracks. Watch for signals indicating an approaching train and never proceed until you are certain it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When driving to an unfamiliar area, you:
questions.answerA: Should depend on road signs to find your way.
questions.answerB: Should plan your trip in advance.
questions.answerC: Only have to know generally where your destination is.
questions.answerD: Should always choose the most direct route.
questions.explanation: When driving to an unfamiliar area, plan your trip in advance. Don’t start with only a hazy idea of where you are going. If your destination is in an unfamiliar area, check the location on a map before you start to drive.

questions.question: Reaction time is slower after:
questions.answerB: Sleeping.
questions.answerC: Working hard.
questions.explanation: Alcohol slows your reflexes and reaction time, reduces your ability to see clearly, and makes you less alert. As the amount of alcohol in your body increases, your judgment worsens and your driving skills decrease. You will have trouble judging distances, speeds, and the movement of other vehicles.

questions.question: What does this road sign indicate?
questions.answerB: School zone ahead
questions.answerC: Playground area ahead
questions.explanation: Pentagonal signs indicate that you are in or are approaching a school zone and/or school crossing. Be aware of children when driving near a school zone and follow posted speed limits.

questions.question: Which of the following lights indicates that you should slow down and proceed with caution at an intersection?
questions.answerB: A flashing red light
questions.answerC: A solid yellow light
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light at an intersection indicates that drivers must slow down, proceed with caution, and be prepared to stop.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Upcoming intersection.
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers of an upcoming intersection so they may prepare for potential traffic or prepare to turn.

questions.question: You are on the freeway and traffic is merging into your lane. You should:
questions.answerA: Make room for the merging traffic, if possible.
questions.answerB: Assert your right-of-way by driving faster.
questions.answerC: Always maintain your position.
questions.explanation: When traffic permits, you should make room to allow vehicles to merge into your lane.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You should stop for other traffic.
questions.answerB: Traffic is entering from another road and you should allow additional space for drivers to merge safely into the flow of traffic.
questions.answerC: Traffic is entering from another road and you should keep right.
questions.explanation: This sign alerts you to the possibility of traffic merging into the main stream of travel. After checking to your side and rear, you should move into another lane, if possible, to allow merging motorists a clear path.

questions.question: Don’t follow other cars too closely because:
questions.answerA: You may not see the road between the cars.
questions.answerB: You may not have time to stop if the vehicle in front of you slows or stops suddenly.
questions.answerC: You may not see the vehicle's turn signals.
questions.answerD: You may not see the other vehicle’s brake lights.
questions.explanation: If you follow too closely and the vehicle in front of you slows or stops suddenly, you may not have enough time to avoid a collision.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection and have a green light. Pedestrians are crossing against the red. You should:
questions.answerB: Speed up and pass in front of the pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Stop to let the pedestrians cross safely.
questions.answerD: Drive close to the pedestrians and frighten them so they’ll think twice before crossing against a red light.
questions.explanation: Yield to pedestrians and cars that may be caught in an intersection when you have a green light. Be careful around pedestrians under every circumstance.

questions.question: To improve visibility lowered by rain or fog, drivers should use their:
questions.answerB: High beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Parking lights.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used when driving in rainy or foggy weather. Even if they do little to help you see, low beams will make it easier for others to see you.

questions.question: You should not start across an intersection if you know you will block the intersection when the light turns red:
questions.answerB: Unless you entered the intersection on a yellow light.
questions.answerC: Unless you entered the intersection on a green light.
questions.explanation: Even if the signal is green, you must not enter an intersection unless you can get completely across before the light turns red. If you block the intersection, you can be cited.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: Right lane closed.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a winding road and that they should adjust their speed accordingly.

questions.question: When driving on gravel or dirt roads:
questions.answerA: Your tires grip the road better than when you are driving on pavement.
questions.answerB: Your tires do not have as much traction as they do on pavement, so you must slow down.
questions.answerC: Visibility is better than on pavement.
questions.explanation: Your tires do not have as much traction on loose gravel and dirt roads as they do on concrete and asphalt roads. When driving on gravel or dirt, you must slow down. It will take you much longer to stop and it is much easier to skid when turning.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: U-turns are permitted.
questions.answerC: Winding road ahead.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. U-turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: While driving at night, you may use your parking lights instead of headlights.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: It is unlawful to drive at night using only your parking lights. You must use your headlights when driving in lowered visibility.

questions.question: When you are in a line of traffic that is crossing a railroad track that has no signals or gates:
questions.answerA: You have the right-of-way and do not need to check for trains.
questions.answerB: You may pass slower drivers while crossing the track.
questions.answerC: You need to make sure there is space for your vehicle to get all the way across the tracks without stopping.
questions.explanation: If you are following another vehicle at a railroad crossing, check to make sure you have enough room to get all the way across before you drive onto the tracks. You should never try to pass another vehicle as you approach or cross a railroad crossing. Always check for trains before crossing any railroad tracks.

questions.question: If a tire blows out, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brake and hold it.
questions.answerB: Hold the steering wheel tightly and use the brakes lightly.
questions.answerC: Pull over quickly.
questions.explanation: If a tire suddenly blows out while you are driving, hold the steering wheel tightly and keep the vehicle going straight.You should slow down gradually, taking your foot off the gas pedal and using the brakes lightly. Do not stop on the road if at all possible. Pull off the road in a safe place.

questions.question: You are turning onto a two-lane road divided by a broken yellow line. You know immediately that:
questions.answerA: You are on a two-way road.
questions.answerB: You are on a one-way road.
questions.answerC: The road is under repair.
questions.answerD: You must stay to the left of the broken yellow lines.
questions.explanation: Yellow centerlines are used to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Broken lines may be crossed to pass slower-moving traffic when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: Left turn yield on green.
questions.explanation: This sign means that a traffic signal is ahead. You should slow down and be prepared to stop.

questions.question: As you approach the top of a hill, you should:
questions.answerB: Prepare to stop, if needed.
questions.answerC: Maintain a steady speed.
questions.explanation: You may not know what is on the other side of a hill or just around a curve, even if you have driven the road many times. If a vehicle is stalled just out of sight on the roadway, you must be able to stop. Whenever you come to a hill or curve, adjust your speed so you can stop if necessary.

questions.question: An "End school zone" sign indicates:
questions.answerA: That the speed limit is 20 mph.
questions.answerB: The beginning of a reduced speed zone.
questions.answerC: The increased possibility of encountering pedestrians.
questions.answerD: The end of a reduced speed zone.
questions.explanation: Do not exceed the school zone speed limit during indicated times. The end of a reduced speed school zone will be indicated by an "End school zone" regulatory sign.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Steep grade ahead.
questions.answerC: Winding road.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that there is a steep hill ahead. Slow down and be ready to shift to a lower gear to control your speed and protect your brakes from damage.

questions.question: This is the shape and color of a ____ sign.
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Yield
questions.explanation: Downward-facing triangular signs mean drivers must yield. When approaching a yield sign, slow down to a speed that is reasonable for existing conditions and stop if necessary. If you must stop, do so at a marked stop line, if it exists.

questions.question: You are driving along a street and hear a siren. You cannot immediately see the emergency vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Keep driving until you see the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Pull to the curb and look to see if it is on your street.
questions.answerC: Slow down. Don't stop until you see it.
questions.answerD: Speed up and turn at the next intersection.
questions.explanation: If you hear a siren or an air horn close by but do not know exactly where the emergency vehicle is, safely pull over to the right side of the road and stop until you are sure it is not headed toward you.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: School zone.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign marks the presence of a crosswalk. Be alert to any pedestrians that may be crossing the roadway.

questions.question: When a car with bright headlights drives toward you at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the other driver passes.
questions.answerB: Look below their headlights.
questions.answerC: Glance toward the right edge of your lane.
questions.explanation: To avoid being blinded when driving at night, do not look directly at the headlights of oncoming cars. Instead, look toward the right edge of the road until the oncoming driver has passed.

questions.question: Your vehicle's stopping distance increases when stopping:
questions.answerA: On a wet or icy road.
questions.answerB: On paved highways.
questions.answerC: When driving at night.
questions.explanation: Stopping distances increase on wet or icy roads. Stopping distances also increase on road surfaces covered in loose gravel or stones.

questions.question: Always signal when:
questions.answerB: Pulling into or out of a parking space.
questions.answerC: Pulling into traffic from an alley or parking area.
questions.explanation: Always use the proper turn signal when changing lanes, pulling into or out of a parking space, or pulling into traffic from an alley or parking area. Communicate with other drivers on the road to help prevent accidents.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Roundabout ahead.
questions.answerC: No U-turns.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs provide notice to road users of traffic laws that must be obeyed. This sign tells drivers that it is prohibited to make a U-turn.

questions.question: What does a traffic signal with a yellow left arrow indicate?
questions.answerA: Drivers should prepare to yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: The protected left turn is about to end.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: When a protected turn arrow changes from green to yellow, drivers must prepare to yield to oncoming traffic. A yellow arrow indicates that the protected left turn is ending.

questions.question: When backing up:
questions.answerB: Press hard on the gas pedal.
questions.answerC: Rely only on your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When backing up, place your right arm on the back of the passenger seat and look directly through the rear window. Do not depend on your rearview or side mirrors as mirrors do not show directly behind your vehicle. Only drive in reverse at a low speed.

questions.question: A U-turn is not permitted:
questions.answerB: On or near any curve or hill.
questions.answerC: On a straight roadway with a clear view for 500 feet in both directions.
questions.explanation: You must never turn around while on or near any curve or hill. You may not be able to see oncoming traffic or pedestrians and may cause a collision.

questions.question: If you have an argument with another person and you are angry, you should:
questions.answerA: Loudly play the radio while driving so you won’t think about your argument.
questions.answerB: Take a few minutes to cool off before driving.
questions.answerC: Drive on the interstate to let off steam.
questions.explanation: Your emotions affect your ability to drive safely. If you are overly angry, excited, afraid, worried, or depressed, you should give yourself time to calm down before operating a vehicle. You need to be able to mentally focus on driving without thinking about the things that made you upset.

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true?
questions.answerA: A two-second following distance may be sufficient under normal conditions for an experienced driver.
questions.answerB: An inexperienced driver should maintain at least a three-second following distance under normal driving conditions.
questions.answerC: At speeds of 40 mph or faster, a four- to five-second following distance is recommended.
questions.explanation: When driving under ideal conditions at speeds slower than 40 mph, experienced drivers should maintain a following distance of at least two seconds. An inexperienced driver should maintain a following distance of at least three seconds. When driving under ideal conditions at speeds above 40 mph, drivers should increase their following distance to four or five seconds. Increase your following distance when anything makes conditions less than ideal.

questions.question: You see pedestrians near the road. You should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn and maintain your speed.
questions.answerB: Speed up to clear the area quickly.
questions.answerC: Slow down and pass with caution.
questions.explanation: Watch for any pedestrian who may cross your path. If you see pedestrians near the road where you are driving, slow down and be prepared to stop, if necessary.

questions.question: In an area with a speed limit of 45 mph or less, you must signal a turn continuously during the last ____ before turning.
questions.answerB: 200 feet
questions.answerC: 300 feet
